t/gh/myreaderx12/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/23/15-18-18-347_a6af1037d546f86b.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/How-to-create.005-900x506.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn68@2020_5/2020/08/23/15-18-18-113_7301b1323b43e811.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/How-to-create.006-900x506.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn28@2020_2/2020/08/23/15-18-17-222_a782d93fa6b518e2.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/2D-300x112.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn44@2020_5/2020/08/23/15-18-17-547_80a861fabd94cd42.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Atmotube-300x154.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn32@2020_4/2020/08/23/15-18-19-201_a772a2662ad7fc1b.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/2-1-900x504.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn32@2020_2/2020/08/23/15-18-24-230_f0b4e9dfa55f29d6.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Imperfections-for-plastic-parts-900x394.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn76@2020_6/2020/08/23/15-18-14-626_c81cfdb3d7c6f6c5.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Defect-900x506.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn68@2020_3/2020/08/23/15-18-12-098_a9cf826205b4d8fe.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195876146},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:49","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:49","title":"How Can a Startup Compete with Big Companies","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=173327","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/08/01/how-can-a-startup-compete-with-big-companies/\" title=\"How Can a Startup Compete with Big Companies\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"169\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/How-Can-a-Startup-Compete-with-Big-Companies-300x169.jpg\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"compete as startup\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/How-Can-a-Startup-Compete-with-Big-Companies-300x169.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/How-Can-a-Startup-Compete-with-Big-Companies-260x146.jpg 260w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/How-Can-a-Startup-Compete-with-Big-Companies.jpg 900w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></div><p>Entering the market flooded by well-known companies is quite a challenge. Yet, not for those who know the market rules and turn them into their advantage. If you’ve founded a startup and aren’t quite sure how to make a way among your renowned competitors, you’ve got to the right article. There’s something you can do. Let&#8217;s take a look at how startups can compete with big companies.</p>\n<h2>Create strong positioning</h2>\n<p>So why should customers choose your brand? Understand what you offer and who you offer it to. If you don’t see what is so special about you, believe me, your clients won’t see either.</p>\n<p>What you really need is a precise and catching positioning. It can be challenging for a small company, but here are some practical tips to start with:</p>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>Study your clients.</b> Make short interviews with your clients. Outline your Ideal Customer Profile. Here&#8217;s <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/04/10/a-startup-guide-to-creating-an-ideal-customer-profile/\">a simple guide</a> to help you move with it. You need to understand what made them choose you over the big guy. Gather all the answers into one pool and outline your strong sides.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>Learn your competitors.</b> Conduct research of your 10-15 nearest competitors. Examine everything they offer: their services, USPs, clients’ reviews (don’t forget about negative ones, you can overrun them here). Think about your niche. It can be either wide or super narrow. Our reality creates new opportunities for new niches. You always can try to make the most of the situation. In the wake of Coronavirus, there are also new directions and niches to jump in. Just dig through some recent trends, statistics, or <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/06/12/new-niches-for-startups-created-by-the-covid-19-pandemic/\">articles</a>.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>Word your USP</b>. Having analyzed your competitors and clients, create a unique and most appealing product offer. It shouldn’t be written on 5 pages, rather short and precise.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>Brainstorm ideas</b> with your team ― there is no need to invent a bicycle again, just find a new way to ride it. If you feel that you need external expertise, outsource a marketing expert or business analyst to help you create a strong positioning.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2><b>Use great storytelling</b></h2>\n<p>When you compete with big brands, good storytelling is essential. Tell stories that impress, charm, and win your customers. Stand out with creativity and a nice brand story. Here’s some inspiration from startups that have done it:</p>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Let’s look at the <a href=\"https://www.dollarshaveclub.com/\">Dollar Shave Club</a> ― a company that delivers razors and other personal grooming products to customers by mail. They’ve used the power of storytelling to create an <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZUG9qYTJMsI\">ad</a> that got over 26M views. The startup got more than 12,000 orders in the first 48 hours.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Another case is the <a href=\"https://www.deathwishcoffee.com/\">Death Wish Coffee</a> company. It uses great storytelling on its website to stand out in a very busy coffee business niche. Just imagine, how can a startup distinguish itself in the coffee industry? But they did it.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The <a href=\"https://saddlebackleather.com/?SID=0d80db99c6adccd701b00ae48896a33e\">Saddleback Leather Co.</a> developed a great legend behind its brand with a 100-year warranty. Just look at their slogan ‘They fight for it when you are dead’. The company sells all sorts of leather goods, including a reusable toilet roll for $1,000,000.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Be convincing. You have to be 100% in love with what you’re doing to make others love it, too. Tell your story with passion, advertise your products with enthusiasm, be proud of what you offer. It’s not only important to attract customers but also to engage investors in supporting your business. Although there are tons of various &#8220;investor hunting&#8221; guides (fulcrum dot rocks) useful and <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2018/08/20/how-to-choose-a-startup-investment/\">explicit articles</a>, communication is still the most effective instrument.</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/notebook-writing-pencil-start-45718.jpg\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-173329 size-large\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/notebook-writing-pencil-start-45718-900x593.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"900\" height=\"593\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/notebook-writing-pencil-start-45718-900x593.jpg 900w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/notebook-writing-pencil-start-45718-300x198.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/notebook-writing-pencil-start-45718-243x160.jpg 243w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/notebook-writing-pencil-start-45718-1536x1012.jpg 1536w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/notebook-writing-pencil-start-45718.jpg 1920w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px\" /></a></p>\n<h2>Go mobile</h2>\n<p>Everybody is going mobile. It’s a fact. Small companies need to adopt newer technologies faster than the big guys. So, catch the trends. Develop a fault-tolerant, smart, new mobile or a web app. Make it as fun and interactive as you can. Don’t overthink it but use the popularity of mobile apps for your benefit. Think through the features your app needs to impress the clients, calculate approximate costs, start developing it.</p>\n<p>How can a startup compete with big companies through an app? Huh, in many ways. After all, it depends greatly on your niche. A really good app enables you to provide extraordinary customer service. It allows you to communicate with your clients and turn them into brand advocates. Finally, a popular app can always bring you additional money through advertising and cooperation models.</p>\n<p>Your app shouldn’t be generic. You can add crazy filters, animations, Easter eggs ― anything to make yourself stand out from the staid and boring big companies who are too scared to be creative. It’s a win-win solution.</p>\n<h2>Be an underdog. It’s cool</h2>\n<p>We watch movies about underdogs all the time. Everyone roots for little guys. For instance, Rudy, Forest Gump, and the Karate Kid have had us digging deep for the unexpected hero, the one who punches above their weight. In the modern world, underdogs rule.</p>\n<p>Thus, <a href=\"https://hbswk.hbs.edu/item/the-consumer-appeal-of-underdog-branding\">Harvard Business School</a> even offers two key factors which help underdogs to win:</p>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>A position that looks like you’re at a disadvantage.</b> As to the study, this seemingly disadvantaged position in the marketplace is critical for business growth ― people do want the underdog to succeed.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>Showing your passion and determination.</b> Being more determined than others about your goals, not giving up, and hitting obstacles along the way gives people hope and shows that success is still possible in a challenging environment. That’s why they are more likely to choose an underdog over a big player who had it all way easier.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>What’s more, <a href=\"https://hbswk.hbs.edu/item/the-consumer-appeal-of-underdog-branding\">Harvard Business School</a> has created a series of studies that have tested how effective an underdog biography can be for a business to increase purchase intention as well as brand loyalty. So, take a look and catch some inspiration from there.</p>\n<h2><b>Go extra mile</b><b> </b></h2>\n<p>Offer your clients extra in everything you do: your product, your customer service, etc. When clients feel that you care about them, they will not just return to you, they will recommend you to others.</p>\n<p>Here are some simple and quite obvious tips on how to compete with big brands through your service:</p>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Always attend to your customers quickly. Set up a quick auto-response for the customers’ inquiries or make sure to hire a 24/7 customer support specialist.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Make regular audits to check the quality of your products and services. You can use the help of your already existing clients. Make a short query asking them what they like and don’t like about your startup. By this, you will do both: find out your gaps and show the customers that you care.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Meet and exceed your promises. Set up high-quality service standards and define your added values. Added Value means something extra to add to your product or service. Study what your clients have to say ― what is the thing they like the most.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2><a href=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/turned-on-pendant-lamp-132340.jpg\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-173330 size-large\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/turned-on-pendant-lamp-132340-900x675.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"900\" height=\"675\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/turned-on-pendant-lamp-132340-900x675.jpg 900w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/turned-on-pendant-lamp-132340-300x225.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/turned-on-pendant-lamp-132340-213x160.jpg 213w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/turned-on-pendant-lamp-132340-1536x1152.jpg 1536w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/turned-on-pendant-lamp-132340.jpg 1920w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px\" /></a></h2>\n<h2>Establish a strong Content Marketing strategy</h2>\n<p>Whatever online strategy you use, your Content Marketing is going to have an impact on every other part of your plan. It’s possibly one of the most important pillars of your Marketing.</p>\n<p>Start building your strong content marketing strategy, make sure that you:</p>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Use a well-planned SEO strategy to get high Google rankings for the customers you want. If your keywords are too competitive, try to use longer ones (LSI Keywords). Here’s a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/seo-strategy?_ga=2.74571604.759571702.1590518345-1568658794.1590518345\">9-step guide</a> to help you with building the right SEO strategy.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Take advantage of the power of Google Ads to increase your audience. PPC (Pay per Click) campaigns are a good way to raise awareness about your startup as well as to attract potential customers.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Don’t underestimate social media. Nowadays it’s a good tool to promote your business. So, harness your social media marketing to engage more customers and develop your brand awareness.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Having good content marketing can be a relatively cheap way to market your brand, but it’s essential for startups because it’s a way to show off your expertise and become an authoritative voice in your industry. In general, digital marketing should not be underestimated before. Not it is becoming one of the strongest sides of your overall marketing strategy. To understand why so, make sure to read this <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/02/25/what-is-digital-marketing-and-why-is-it-important-for-startups/\">brief yet informative piece</a>.</p>\n<h2>Wrapping up</h2>\n<p>Competing with big brands isn’t an easy task, but it makes the game all the more interesting! After all, famous brands don’t have your creativity, your bold ideas and courage.</p>\n<p>The success of your business is in your hands, not sitting in the clutches of your biggest competitors.</p>\n<p>So, here’s just one more reminder of things you need to get done:</p>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Work on strong positioning of your startup</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Attract everyone’s attention with your storytelling</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Invest in a fault-tolerant, mobile/web app</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Go extra mile for your clients</li>\n</ul>\n<p>My best advice for you is this: Don’t second guess. Don’t wait. Don’t be hesitant. Do it.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/08/01/how-can-a-startup-compete-with-big-companies/\">How Can a Startup Compete with Big Companies</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 01 Aug 2020 15:00:51 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/How-Can-a-Startup-Compete-with-Big-Companies.jpg","linkMd5":"61f671b3a03bfd4570b05a64cfd24fb0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn12@2020_3/2020/08/23/15-18-25-638_b3f347b11b255a7b.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/How-Can-a-Startup-Compete-with-Big-Companies.jpg","destWidth":900,"destHeight":506,"sourceBytes":24356,"destBytes":19244,"author":"Kate Khalimonchuk","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/How-Can-a-Startup-Compete-with-Big-Companies-300x169.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn15@2020_3/2020/08/23/15-18-11-802_73812fe704310ce4.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/notebook-writing-pencil-start-45718-900x593.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn75@2020_5/2020/08/23/15-18-13-716_dde5a0d311e417e2.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/turned-on-pendant-lamp-132340-900x675.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn64@2020_3/2020/08/23/15-18-17-644_c0ea222367e74f6f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195869606},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:53","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:53","title":"What Engineering Leaders are Doing to Boost Their Teams’ Well-Being and Productivity While WFH","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=174779","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/07/22/what-engineering-leaders-are-doing-to-boost-their-teams-well-being-and-productivity-while-wfh/\" title=\"What Engineering Leaders are Doing to Boost Their Teams’ Well-Being and Productivity While WFH\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"200\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/woman-sitting-while-operating-macbook-pro-1181676-300x200.jpg\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/woman-sitting-while-operating-macbook-pro-1181676-300x200.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/woman-sitting-while-operating-macbook-pro-1181676-900x601.jpg 900w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/woman-sitting-while-operating-macbook-pro-1181676-240x160.jpg 240w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/woman-sitting-while-operating-macbook-pro-1181676-1536x1026.jpg 1536w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/woman-sitting-while-operating-macbook-pro-1181676.jpg 1920w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></div><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Since March, much of the workforce has shifted to a remote work environment in accordance with social distancing recommendations. According to </span><a href=\"https://www.pwc.com/us/covid-19-employee-survey\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">PwC’s Workforce Pulse Survey</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, companies’ COVID-19 safety measures are now table stakes. Working remotely may be a reality for the foreseeable future, as many employees are not confident that safety measures like mandatory testing, shut-down protocols, hygiene policies, and contact tracing, will keep them safe. Only 36% of the </span><a href=\"https://blog.namely.com/software-developers-return-to-office\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">150+ </span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">developers</span><a href=\"https://blog.namely.com/software-developers-return-to-office\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> Coderbyte surveyed</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> said that they are eager to return to the office. </span></p>\n<p><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-174780 size-full\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Screen-Shot-2020-07-20-at-12.48.29-PM.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"623\" height=\"275\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Screen-Shot-2020-07-20-at-12.48.29-PM.png 623w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Screen-Shot-2020-07-20-at-12.48.29-PM-300x132.png 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Screen-Shot-2020-07-20-at-12.48.29-PM-260x115.png 260w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 623px) 100vw, 623px\" /></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Regardless of what the future of work holds, engineering leaders are adapting how they </span><a href=\"https://blog.namely.com/transition-to-remote-product-development\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">manage</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> and </span><a href=\"https://resources.workable.com/stories-and-insights/how-to-boost-your-remote-tech-hiring-in-a-remote-first-world/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">hire</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> remote development teams. For those that have been furloughed or laid off, now is the time to reinvent habits and skills for a new economy. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">I talked to six uplifting engineering leaders from Lambda School, Friendbuy and others to understand their perspectives and recommendations on how to keep moving forward during this radical shift in the way we work.</span></p>\n<h2><b>Engineering leaders</b></h2>\n<p><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-174863 size-full\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Screen-Shot-2020-07-22-at-1.58.44-PM.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"575\" height=\"731\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Screen-Shot-2020-07-22-at-1.58.44-PM.png 575w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Screen-Shot-2020-07-22-at-1.58.44-PM-236x300.png 236w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Screen-Shot-2020-07-22-at-1.58.44-PM-566x719.png 566w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Screen-Shot-2020-07-22-at-1.58.44-PM-126x160.png 126w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 575px) 100vw, 575px\" /></p>\n<h2><b>Increasing productivity and maintaining focus while working remotely</b></h2>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Organizing chaos, which is also one of Lambda School&#8217;s values, has allowed me and my teams to continue to be productive when so many operating procedures have changed. Since we no longer have the benefit of nudging the person sitting next to us and seeking help, we need to ensure that help is available when needed. Improving our documentation and making it discoverable is one of the best ways to make this happen. I encourage my teams to create new documentation as much as possible and update the existing ones. This has allowed us to ensure smooth onboarding of new hires, properly manage projects and project status, consistently document and update tribal knowledge, run efficient processes, and more without the luxury of nudging your neighbor.”<br />\n</span><b>– Himanshu Gahlot</b></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“There are many things that I take advantage of in order to stay up-to-date with </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">engineering trends. It’s about having a mindset of learning and constantly improving. I’ve </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">found that when you have that attitude, your brain automatically picks up </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">information when you least expect it. For example, when browsing LinkedIn for </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">potential candidates or scrolling through Twitter, I might come across an article on tech or process </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">improvement or notice what the </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">people I follow are liking or retweeting. I’ve been fortunate in my career to have </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">built strong relationships with some of the best engineering minds in the industry. </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">I’m frequently in touch with them and we discuss engineering related topics often. I</span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">t’s become a great source for me to dig deeper into things that I either find </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">interesting or help me solve a problem. Other than that, I follow the </span><a href=\"https://softwareengineeringdaily.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Software </span></a><a href=\"https://softwareengineeringdaily.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Engineering Daily</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> podcast. I regularly visit the engineering blogs of companies with strong engineering cultures to see how others are solving their problems.”<br />\n</span><b>– Nimish Parmar</b></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“I&#8217;ve invested in improving my workspace to help me with productivity and health. Because of the lack of activity, I&#8217;ve got both a standing desk and an ergonomic chair. I&#8217;ve also created a workspace separate from where I rest in order to keep things organized and disciplined.”<br />\n</span><b>– Arjun Srivastava</b></p>\n<h2><b>Improving morale and maintaining culture</b></h2>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“I&#8217;ve been spending more time implementing ways to boost team morale during quarantine. To that effect, I have been collaborating with other engineering leaders in the company to organize virtual outings (e.g. GoGame virtual game), virtual happy hours, making meetings more fun and useful for the team by altering meeting agendas to include topics that interest the team, and so on. I think these are some of the most worthwhile investments I have made professionally, which are already showing positive outcomes in the form of improved team health and vibe as measured by regular team surveys and feedback.”<br />\n</span><b>– Himanshu Gahlot</b></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Home Partners is driven extensively by social interaction and networking between employees.  With social distancing and the complete work from home roll-out, our company took several steps to ensure continuity of such culture:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Several virtual clubs were created on Microsoft Teams for people to share their off-work activities during quarantine.</span></li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Every day, there&#8217;s a company-wide email sent out called &#8220;Daily Dose&#8221; with internet memes and other satirical pictures/videos on the current situation.</span></li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">None of the company-wide all hands were canceled; all of them regularly happened virtually.</span></li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The company continued to celebrate birthdays, anniversaries, and other milestone events for employees once a month virtually.</span></li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Individual groups organized virtual happy hours and social connecting events like game evenings.</span></li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">In the absence of face-to-face connection, the number of meetings and stand-ups went up in order to over-communicate daily work activities.”<br />\n</span><b>– Anshul Agarwal</b></li>\n</ul>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“We have a distributed team that’s spread out across the world, including Uruguay, Philippines, and Egypt, which comes with added challenges when not everyone has met each other in person. When we first started our virtual weekly coffee hour, the turn out wasn’t great. Then we assigned someone to plan a few questions and games for each session, which helped everyone to open up. Now people volunteer to help with any planning, and it’s something everyone looks forward to every week. The company can plan structured events first, and if employees enjoy it, they’ll want to keep it going themselves.”<br />\n</span><b>– Dan Zhou</b></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“We believe that company culture is a set of beliefs and behaviors that we embody </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">every single day. In that regard, nothing’s changed. However, we’re communicating </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">and collaborating a lot more across the board to make sure that we’re upholding </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">our values consistently. We host virtual happy hours within the company regularly. We’re also trying out virtual events via </span><a href=\"https://www.offsyte.co/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Offsyte.co</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">”<br />\n</span><b>– Nimish Parmar</b></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Although our company structure adopted remote working long before quarantine, we would usually have in-person team dinners, outings and gatherings to bring everyone together and allow human connection. During quarantine, Biscuit &#38; Chai is maintaining this by having the occasional team lunch delivered to everyone with a zoom meetup where we all take a break and just talk about fun things, creating slack channels to share fun memes and/or just talk about hobbies, interests, ideas and support, and we are even planning a group virtual karaoke.”<br />\n</span><b>– Arjun Srivastava</b></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“We try to have video chats to mimic face to face conversations very often, as well as doing group activities like physical exercises over a video call. The tech team is usually on group calls from morning to evening to mimic the environment of the office. This isn&#8217;t a must or only to discuss work but also to joke with each other and have random conversations like we usually would have in the office.”<br />\n</span><b>– Kushal Patel</b></p>\n<h2><b>Installing feedback loops for continuous improvement</b></h2>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> &#8220;As an engineering leader, it is very important for me to gather feedback from my team on how they are feeling about their work, peers, manager, etc. With the transition to fully remote work, it has become a bit difficult for managers to understand the vibe in the team because you may not get to meet with your team members outside of explicit meetings. We no longer have hallway conversations and there are no morning greetings or team lunches or coffee breaks or one-off conversations. Chat/text based conversations are often not enough to understand the true feelings and may lead to misunderstandings. Therefore, a manager needs better ways to understand the general vibe in the team. I have started relying, now more than ever, on team surveys, feedback, and sprint retrospectives to understand my teams&#8217; health and take proactive actions on issues reported by the team. While team surveys and sprint retrospectives have always been part of my management strategy, my reliance on them have increased a lot more in this transition to fully remote work. I use </span><a href=\"http://officevibe.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">officevibe.com</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> and </span><a href=\"https://www.retrospect.team/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">retrospect.team</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> for team surveys/feedback and sprint retrospectives, respectively.&#8221;<br />\n</span><b>– Himanshu Gahlot</b></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“</span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">One of the best investments I&#8217;ve made for my team during quarantine is to allow them more time for their personal and professional growth. I rolled out a growth plan program for my team where I conducted individual sessions with my reports to understand their growth needs, chart out a plan of activities they&#8217;d like to pursue, and plan how they could accelerate some of the growth items during quarantine with additional time available. My team, while delivering on the business requests and regular project work, is now also able to focus on skill development personally driven by them.”<br />\n</span><b>– Anshul Agarwal</b></p>\n<h2><b>Advice for developers looking for jobs during the pandemic</b></h2>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“One of the most important skills that companies seek in software engineering candidates is their algorithmic and coding ability. Job seekers should continue to refine this skill. This can be achieved in various ways, including but not limited to, enrolling in relevant online courses, sharpening their coding skills through </span><a href=\"https://leetcode.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">LeetCode</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">/</span><a href=\"https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/get-your-dream-job-with-amazon-sde-test-series/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">GeekForGeeks</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, learning skills which are most relevant for today&#8217;s job market by enrolling in online bootcamps like </span><a href=\"https://lambdaschool.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Lambda School</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, reading relevant books, and so on.”<br />\n</span><b>– Himanshu Gahlot</b></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“One of the challenges about being furloughed is that you may be faced with the uncertainty of not knowing when your company will bring you back. Everyone’s situation is unique, and some people have immediate responsibilities and need to prioritize finding a new job. But if you have the financial runway, this could be the time to do something you’ve always wanted to do. I have friends and colleagues who are taking online classes with the goal of making a career transition, going back to school for a graduate degree, or even considering starting their own businesses. The opportunity cost has never been lower to try something new.”<br />\n</span><b>– Dan Zhou</b></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Jobs may not be as easy to come by, so keep yourself occupied and if a job does come your way, do not let the opportunity pass you by, especially if you need to keep yourself moving. Learn a new technology and keep yourself up to date with the latest trends. Also, do what you are passionate about and keep yourself busy, so that you don&#8217;t end up with more mental stress. It might also make sense to look for remote opportunities to keep yourself going.”<br />\n</span><b>– Kushal Patel</b></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“There’s no sugarcoating it. Getting let go, laid off or furloughed sucks. A lot! So I’m </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">going to stay away from cliches and keep it real. These are unprecedented times, but at the same time, if you’re an engineer, you have everything it takes to succeed. There might be many reasons for not being fully employed right now, but there’s a high probability that most of them have nothing to do with you or your capabilities. The whole world has been turned upside down. Companies and businesses have to rethink their entire business models. There are countless articles out there to help you prepare, but here are some practical tips from me:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Start reaching out to your network immediately, if you haven’t done so already. Reach out to every single person you think could even remotely help you in any way possible. You might have helped others throughout your career, but this is the time to reach out and ask for help.</span></li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Post on LinkedIn and other social media platforms if you’ve been furloughed. You’ll be surprised at how many people are willing to help you. Random strangers might pass along your profile to someone who might be able to help you in the most unexpected way. Don’t underestimate the network effect. People are a lot more willing to help these days, and every single view/comment/message helps.</span></li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Practice your interviewing skills. That means not just brushing up on algorithms, data structures and other relevant technical topics, but being fully prepared for all aspects of a technical interview. As a hiring manager, I strongly value drive, hunger and passion for delivering results, a collaborative mindset, clear and concise communication skills and friendly personality. Non-technical skills matter more than you think. Technical skills might be easier to acquire, but acquiring soft skills might be much more difficult.</span></li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Interview, interview and interview. The more interviews you do, the higher your chances of landing a new career that fits your criteria. Learn from each interview and improve. Put the classic Agile iterative process in action.</span></li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Above all, have a positive mindset. Engineering skills are very much in demand. Hiring top notch talent is still challenging for companies and you can use that to your advantage.”<br />\n</span><b>– Nimish Parmar</b></li>\n</ul>\n<h2><b>Predictions about the future of hiring</b></h2>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Since many companies are going fully remote and most others are planning to provide this as a recommended option going forward, software engineering processes need to adjust themselves to become better compliant with remote work. A few companies like Gitlab and Basecamp have been operating as fully remote companies. They have published extensive </span><a href=\"https://about.gitlab.com/company/culture/all-remote/guide/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">guides</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> on how working remotely can be made really efficient. I think, going forward, more companies will start adopting the best practices outlined by these companies. There is still a lot to be seen and learned in this new way of working which will be uncovered when different kinds of companies (e.g. differently sized, different kinds of products, mobile development and testing vs. simple web based products, etc.) start figuring out best practices of remote work that suit them. Fortunately, software engineering is one of the most suitable jobs for remote work, so it would be interesting to see how it tries to achieve the same or better level of productivity as the pre-remote era.”<br />\n</span><b>– Himanshu Gahlot</b></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“The pandemic has proved that technology can keep businesses going even if people are not physically present in their place of work; also, that many sectors and verticals can adopt technology to progress. Thus, the demand for software engineering is going to skyrocket, and remote working will definitely become a more prominent practice. </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Face-to-face interviews have been replaced with assessment tools leading the process, followed by a video chat to formalize the process. The need for assessment and psychometric tests have become even more important now and are in high demand.”<br />\n</span><b>– Kushal Patel</b></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“The biggest change will obviously be in how teams collaborate. Humans have a </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">tremendous ability to adapt. I wasn’t a huge fan of working from home pre-COVID, but after being </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">pretty much forced into working remotely, I feel like we at Friendbuy have adapted </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">quite well. Besides the Zoom fatigue towards the end of the day, it’s been quite </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">effective. We strongly emphasize the importance of collaboration and </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">communication. Our Slack channels are ever more active. Our communication style </span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">has become frequent and impactful.”<br />\n</span><b>– Nimish Parmar</b></p>\n<h2><b>Additional resources</b></h2>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">At Coderbyte, we’re committed to helping forward-thinking technical talent acquisition leaders make an impact. We’ve put together a </span><a href=\"https://insights.coderbyte.com/covid-19\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">COVID-19 Report &#38; Best Practices Guide</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> based on surveying hundreds of software developers to better understand perceptions about remote work and company culture.</span></p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/07/22/what-engineering-leaders-are-doing-to-boost-their-teams-well-being-and-productivity-while-wfh/\">What Engineering Leaders are Doing to Boost Their Teams’ Well-Being and Productivity While WFH</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 22 Jul 2020 12:01:02 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/woman-sitting-while-operating-macbook-pro-1181676.jpg","linkMd5":"e5cd9bd8eb1a12d13453b743fed09590","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn24@2020_3/2020/08/23/15-18-25-806_3dbbaf724ac637c1.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/woman-sitting-while-operating-macbook-pro-1181676.jpg","destWidth":1920,"destHeight":1282,"sourceBytes":181867,"destBytes":127042,"author":"Daniel Borowski","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/woman-sitting-while-operating-macbook-pro-1181676-300x200.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn83@2020_1/2020/08/23/15-18-17-616_d78ca0f3062a20d0.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Screen-Shot-2020-07-20-at-12.48.29-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn99@2020_6/2020/08/23/15-18-14-012_3e3f4b3ae3592785.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Screen-Shot-2020-07-22-at-1.58.44-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn91@2020_2/2020/08/23/15-18-12-663_4b5ec520b8d73b1a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195873518},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:54","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:54","title":"Can Other Industries Replicate MyWorkChoice’s Manufacturing Overhaul?","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=172596","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/06/15/can-other-industries-replicate-myworkchoices-manufacturing-overhaul/\" title=\"Can Other Industries Replicate MyWorkChoice’s Manufacturing Overhaul?\"><img width=\"266\" height=\"300\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Screen-Shot-2020-06-09-at-10.09.02-AM-266x300.png\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Screen-Shot-2020-06-09-at-10.09.02-AM-266x300.png 266w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Screen-Shot-2020-06-09-at-10.09.02-AM-142x160.png 142w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Screen-Shot-2020-06-09-at-10.09.02-AM.png 518w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 266px) 100vw, 266px\" /></a></div><p>Automation is often seen as <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/03/06/why-automation-is-the-only-path-forward-for-manufacturing/\">manufacturers’ ticket</a> to the future. Lately, however, it’s a new labor model that has been drawing jealous stares from other sectors. </p>\n<p>Upending how manufacturers get work done are platforms like <a href=\"http://myworkchoice.com\">MyWorkChoice</a>, an hourly workforce management platform. MyWorkChoice uses smart matching technology to build custom communities, onboarded according to each client’s specifications. </p>\n<p>By letting workers choose their shifts, MyWorkChoice cuts manufacturers’ absenteeism rates from around 35 percent to just 3 percent. For plant output, managers’ stress levels, and company culture, that’s a night-and-day difference. </p>\n<p>The question: Could MyWorkChoice’s model work for other industries? Maybe so — but only if they can fit two puzzle pieces that, frustratingly, never seem to go together: flexibility and dependability.</p>\n<h2><strong>Engineered for Flexibility</strong></h2>\n<p>For years, many white-collar workers have enjoyed the flexibility to work when and where they want. Until recently, however, blue-collar sectors like manufacturing have pigeonholed workers into 40-hour-per-week arrangements. </p>\n<p>Understandably, blue-collar workers want those same freedoms. What broke the dam, according to MyWorkChoice CEO Tana Greene, is the coronavirus pandemic. </p>\n<p>“The traditional staffing agency model is dead,” <a href=\"https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/myworkchoice-connects-essential-supply-chain-companies-to-healthy-workers-amid-covid-19-pandemic-301041075.html?tc=eml_cleartime\">explains Greene</a>. “Prior to the pandemic, flexibility was supporting both workers and companies who needed to scale their workforce at any given time; today it’s a critical piece of the puzzle to keep our supply chain moving and put healthy people to work.”</p>\n<p>Instead of requiring a rigid schedule, MyWorkChoice lets the company’s regular workforce sign up for four-hour blocks on the days they choose. Many opt to work a full 40 hours per week, producing a dependable primary workforce. </p>\n<p>Workers understand that MyWorkChoice isn’t just another day-labor app, nor is it a split-shift system. They stick with it because of its flexibility, enabling the companies they serve to build tenured hourly teams.</p>\n<p>Could sectors outside of manufacturing make that model work? Sure, Greene says: MyWorkChoice has applied it to <a href=\"https://vimeo.com/402762105/6072969eed\">call centers</a>, distribution centers, and more. But before they make the leap, they need to solve for the second part of the equation: dependability. </p>\n<h2><strong>Solved with Scale</strong></h2>\n<p>Shorter shifts are a big reason why MyWorkChoice delivers workers reliably. But there’s a second factor that, for industries looking to follow the manufacturing sector’s lead, may be more difficult to replicate: scale.</p>\n<p>Largely because of the flexibility it offers workers, MyWorkChoice is the largest recruiter in most markets it operates in. That ensures it has the bench strength to make the model work, covering gaps in a company’s regular workforce. Access to a larger, scalable workforce creates a secondary line of defense while eliminating the need for overtime.</p>\n<p>A larger labor pool, combined with shorter shifts, lets employers accommodate all sorts of life situations. The result is MyWorkChoice’s third talent stream: nontraditional workforce segments, such as seniors and college students, who wouldn’t otherwise look for manufacturing work. </p>\n<p>Many of these MyWorkChoice workers have responsibilities outside the platform that would make it tough to work longer shifts. Its model makes tough-to-fill times less onerous. For example, the second shift is typically the most difficult to fill, but when flexible four-hour slots are made available, stay-at-home parents and second incomers flock to this shift, making it one of the most coveted on the platform.   </p>\n<p>In the industries MyWorkChoice operates in — manufacturing, call centers, and warehousing — that three-pronged approach proves flexibility works. In more niche ones, it may not.</p>\n<p>Take surveying. According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, there are <a href=\"https://www.bls.gov/ooh/architecture-and-engineering/surveyors.htm\">fewer than 50,000 surveyors</a> in the entire U.S. Because it’s a specialized field, no amount of flexibility could help employers build secondary and tertiary teams. In all but the largest of labor markets, there simply aren’t enough surveyors to go around.</p>\n<h2><strong>Making Flexible Work Work</strong></h2>\n<p>Plenty of industries struggle to fill open positions, despite the economic downturn. Plenty of workers in them want flexibility. So what can employers in other sectors do to marry the two?</p>\n<p>One option is to transition hourly workers to an employer-of-record model. Because MyWorkChoice is the employer of record, it handles worker’s compensation, unemployment claims, and other back-office matters that employers otherwise have to deal with. </p>\n<p>The other option is to bring new demographic groups into the fold. Look for ways to increase flexibility: If possible in your industry, consider making work-from-home options permanent. If not, perhaps you could give workers more choice over their hours. </p>\n<p>The final ingredient? Client service. MyWorkChoice provides regional managers to its clients, ensuring that workers are happy, safe, and getting the job done. </p>\n<p>Without someone on the ground who knows the rules, no amount of software can make workforce management a hands-off process in industries like manufacturing. Technology can make matches, but it takes a human being to make sure those matches actually work out. </p>\n<p>Great client service exists in every industry, as do flexibility and reliable workforces. In manufacturing, what MyWorkChoice has done is put them together in a lasting, harmonious way. Whether that can be done in every industry, however, is a challenge waiting to be conquered.</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/06/15/can-other-industries-replicate-myworkchoices-manufacturing-overhaul/\">Can Other Industries Replicate MyWorkChoice’s Manufacturing Overhaul?</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 15 Jun 2020 14:01:03 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Screen-Shot-2020-06-09-at-10.09.02-AM-266x300.png","linkMd5":"c2733ca40397dda7730da449ec15f7fe","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn51@2020_1/2020/08/23/15-18-07-809_53f48a0fe5e4ed08.webp","destWidth":266,"destHeight":300,"sourceBytes":134054,"destBytes":17516,"author":"Brad Anderson","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Screen-Shot-2020-06-09-at-10.09.02-AM-266x300.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn51@2020_1/2020/08/23/15-18-07-809_53f48a0fe5e4ed08.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195874872},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:48","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:48","title":"The New Customer Buying Experience in a Post-COVID-19 World","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=173688","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/08/13/the-new-customer-buying-experience-in-a-post-covid-19-world/\" title=\"The New Customer Buying Experience in a Post-COVID-19 World\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"185\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-New-Customer-Buying-Experience-in-a-Post-COVID-300x185.jpeg\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"customer buying post covid\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-New-Customer-Buying-Experience-in-a-Post-COVID-300x185.jpeg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-New-Customer-Buying-Experience-in-a-Post-COVID-260x160.jpeg 260w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-New-Customer-Buying-Experience-in-a-Post-COVID.jpeg 825w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></div><p>COVID-19 has accelerated the move to digital, and forced buyers’ hands to fully embrace and adopt e-commerce.</p>\n<p>Research from Adobe’s latest Digital Economy Index shows that <a href=\"https://theblog.adobe.com/online-shopping-during-covid-19-exceeds-2019-holiday-season-levels/\">online shopping during COVID-19</a> has exceeded 2019 holiday season levels and online spend for April and May is $52 billion more than what retailers typically see during those months.</p>\n<h3>E-commerce has just aged three years in the span of three months.</h3>\n<p>The substantial increase in e-commerce transactions has put unprecedented strains and pressures on retail operations and systems. And things aren’t going to go back to “the way they were” either.  In fact, most Americans are still skittish about <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-24/mall-shoppers-are-scared-to-return-when-u-s-stores-finally-open\">visiting stores and malls</a>, according to a First Insights survey.</p>\n<h4>Retailers</h4>\n<p>For retailers, this means strategy overhauls of how they <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/06/26/brands-flock-to-voice-search-as-2020-goes-contactless/\">sell both online and, in their brick and mortar locations</a>. We’re already seeing merchants, both big and small, think out of the box as they digitize their customer interactions and become more experiential.</p>\n<p>There are companies that are ahead of the game, going all in on digital even before the pandemic. Below, we take a look at some of their shrewd ideas and how these may become industry standards post COVID-19.</p>\n<h4><strong>Rethinking Brick and Mortar</strong></h4>\n<p>Given current conditions, we will likely see many brands rethinking the purpose of their brick and mortar locations. There are already first movers in this space, where their storefront is more about telling the brand story, while the actual transactions take place online.</p>\n<p>COVID-19 has taught people that in most cases, buying online can be better, faster, easier, more convenient, and safer. Retailers must make their in-store location worth the trip.</p>\n<h4>Tesla</h4>\n<p>Back in 2019 Tesla made the controversial decision to stop selling its vehicles in showrooms, moving all sales to an online-only model. Their showrooms are <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fnFvXwpm2To\">experience centers</a>, not sales centers.</p>\n<p>If you want to buy a Tesla in a showroom, you can, but it’s a DIY process. You have to pull out your mobile phone, pull up the Tesla website, and order the car. There’s no pushy sales staff who take your order for you.</p>\n<p>Instead, the staff are <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/07/22/how-to-turn-your-buyers-into-brand-believers/\">brand ambassadors</a>, there to help you fall in love with the company and its cars.</p>\n<h4>Focus on direct-to-consumer&#8217;s</h4>\n<p>On a recent earnings call, Jonathan Sinclair, CFO of Canada Goose, explained that the company would be pivoting to focus more on its <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/05/27/paving-the-way-3-industries-ripe-for-post-pandemic-change/\">direct-to-consumer</a> (D2C) business, both through e-commerce and its own <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2019/12/04/canada-gooses-new-toronto-store-has-a-daily-snowstorm.html\">branded experience centers</a>.</p>\n<p>In its flagship Toronto store, there are no products for sale. Instead, consumers get a multi-sensory experience to “feel” why the company’s parkas are worth the hefty price-tag, which is often upwards of $1,000 for a coat.</p>\n<p>Canada Goose also intends to reduce its reliance on wholesale and retail distribution channels going forward.</p>\n<h3><strong>Online-Only Sales Model</strong></h3>\n<p>In some cases, expect companies to close their physical stores altogether and continue business solely online.</p>\n<p>Bose, which in January announced that it would be shutting all of its stores in North America, Europe, Japan, and Australia, definitely saw the writing on the wall even before COVID-19 hit the United States.</p>\n<p>The retailer decided that it would continue its business online only, and when you think about it, no one really needs to try on noise canceling headphones or test speakers in a store.</p>\n<p>Today, <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/11/16/8-key-components-to-building-a-successful-business-online/\">consumers trust online reviews</a> and content more than they do a sales pitch from an associate. It was time for a radical new idea from Bose.</p>\n<h4>Microsoft</h4>\n<p>In a surprise move, Microsoft also just announced they will permanently close all of the 83 their retail stores and shift to a 100% digital retail model.</p>\n<p>The firm is not planning to furlough any of their associates, instead inviting them to take new roles helping customers on their website through video and chat experiences.</p>\n<h4>Zara</h4>\n<p>Looking at some of the recent earnings calls from big retailers, they have seen a seismic shift in their business model. E-commerce has been the survival pill during the pandemic.</p>\n<p>For example, online sales were up 50 percent year over year in Q2 for Zara, and in April alone, its e-commerce sales were up 95 percent. In response, Zara has now updated its online sales growth forecast.</p>\n<p>In 2019, just 14 percent of its revenue came from digital. By 2022, Zara expects e-commerce to account for 25 percent of all the revenues.</p>\n<h3><strong>A Focus on Building Community</strong></h3>\n<p>It’s no longer just about the <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/07/25/how-to-turn-your-sales-to-absolutely-what-you-want/\">sales support</a> you get while you&#8217;re buying the product, or the service and help you get once you own it. It’s about the end-to-end customer experience.</p>\n<p>After more than three months of the pandemic, many companies are realizing continued success will be just as much about how people perceive and engage with the brand. The experience starts from that first engagement, continues through to purchase—and beyond.</p>\n<p>We’ll see a lot more <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/06/24/5-product-discovery-tips-for-building-solutions-customers-will-buy/\">brand-affinity</a> building from retailers, such as community initiatives that customers feel aligned to, and that may give them a voice.</p>\n<h4>Many examples of online communities</h4>\n<p>There’s no better example of this than what Calvin McDonald, the CEO of Lululemon, talked about in June during the company’s 2020 future earnings call.</p>\n<p>During the early days of the pandemic, Lululemon launched an online community where customers could congregate to share their stories, experiences, and continue to do yoga together in a virtual manner.</p>\n<p>Lululemon also built a new chat program, its digital educator service. Using FaceTime and Zoom, customers can book appointments with “store associates” for a virtual video chat about yoga wear that’s right for them.</p>\n<p>Lululemon has essentially taken what was happening in the physical store and digitalized it.</p>\n<h3><strong>It’s Not What’s Coming, It’s What’s Here in Buying<br />\n</strong></h3>\n<p>The future of digital in retail is actually here now.</p>\n<p>As it’s said, “necessity is the mother of all invention,” and this is what we’ve seen because of COVID-19.</p>\n<p>Unfortunately, we will see negative repercussions some businesses have faced in light of the pandemic.</p>\n<p>We will also see some really inspirational stories around resilience over the next couple of months, and how thinking outside of the box and digital-first, can future-proof a brand.</p>\n<p><em>Image Credit: Adobe Stock</em></p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/08/13/the-new-customer-buying-experience-in-a-post-covid-19-world/\">The New Customer Buying Experience in a Post-COVID-19 World</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 13 Aug 2020 21:01:01 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-New-Customer-Buying-Experience-in-a-Post-COVID.jpeg","linkMd5":"6c1cff5aadf167000719762fda84ced6","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn80@2020_2/2020/08/23/15-18-26-135_9e3d9f57587253e6.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-New-Customer-Buying-Experience-in-a-Post-COVID.jpeg","destWidth":825,"destHeight":510,"sourceBytes":46912,"destBytes":39228,"author":"Peter Sheldon","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-New-Customer-Buying-Experience-in-a-Post-COVID-300x185.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn44@2020_1/2020/08/23/15-18-28-287_c55af2f0bdee1267.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195868619},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:48","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:48","title":"PandaDoc Raises $30M to Lead a Paradigm Shift in eSignature Market","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=175621","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/08/10/pandadoc-raises-30m-to-lead-a-paradigm-shift-in-esignature-market/\" title=\"PandaDoc Raises $30M to Lead a Paradigm Shift in eSignature Market\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"200\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/PandaDoc-Raises-30M-to-Lead-a-Paradigm-Shift-in-eSignature-Market-300x200.jpg\" class=\"attachment-medium eSignature industry’s pioneers have been selling &#8211; more or less &#8211; the same product for almost 20 years. The basic functionality is the same across a growing number of vendors, and the service usually comes at a high cost for unlimited business use.</p>\n<p>Still, the industry has enjoyed continued growth as part of a more substantial shift toward digital transformation, making way for significant acquisitions and IPOs and further market saturation.</p>\n<p>As electronic signatures have increased in popularity, they’ve become the gold standard for getting a deal done. But, an urgency in today’s post-COVID world displays that a paradigm shift is well in order.</p>\n<h3><strong>The $25B+ electronic signature market is due for a shakeup</strong></h3>\n<p>As the pandemic continues to change our everyday lives and the way we conduct business, it’s becoming increasingly important to find all-in-one solutions that deliver on the workflow needs for remote teams, helping them continue working effectively and efficiently.</p>\n<p>Adaptability and competence are in contrast to the limited capabilities provided by the traditional, singular use of eSignatures solution.</p>\n<p>The document automation solution company &#8211; <a href=\"http://www.pandadoc.com\">PandaDoc</a> &#8211; is working to change how businesses think about their eSignature solutions.</p>\n<h3><strong> eSignature Disruption</strong></h3>\n<p>Making this innovation possible, the company just received $30 million in a Series B extension led by new investors One Peak and participation from returning investors, Microsoft&#8217;s Venture Fund (M12), Savano Capital Partners, Rembrandt Venture Partners, and EBRD Venture Capital Investment Programme.</p>\n<p>Entrepreneur, investor, and former RingCentral COO, David Sipes, also participated as an investor in this round and will join the PandaDoc Board of Directors.</p>\n<h2><b>PandaDoc is all you need for document automation </b></h2>\n<p>PandaDoc has an all-in-one <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2016/01/25/startup-business-global-expansion/\">document automation software that streamlines the process</a> of creating, approving, and eSigning proposals, quotes, and contracts – and their eSign plan is <i>free</i>.</p>\n<p>“Electronic signatures are important &#8212; they are the final part of closing a deal and today, eSignatures are helping to keep businesses running while we all social distance. That’s why electronic signatures have always been a part of our DNA and why we felt strongly at the start of the pandemic that businesses needed a free solution,” said Mikita Mikado, PandaDoc CEO and Co-Founder.</p>\n<p>“But, eSigning is just the tip of the iceberg. Once you adopt eSignatures, you quickly realize it’s not enough &#8212; you need to automate the generation of these documents, you need to edit them, you need to streamline and track approval workflows, and more. These solutions are where PandaDoc shines.”</p>\n<h3><b> PandaDoc’s Free eSign plan</b></h3>\n<p>Launched in March, PandaDoc’s Free eSign plan is a forever free product that allows customers to upload, send, and collect signatures on an unlimited number of documents for an unlimited number of users. To date, the plan has seen new sign-ups in the tens of thousands and product usage at twice the average rate.</p>\n<p>As free eSign users become familiar with PandaDoc, they often discover a need for broader document automation capabilities, which is where the company’s paid plans fit. While adoption of their product has made them a leader in the eSignature market, it’s helped to propel PandaDoc beyond 20,000 paying customers.</p>\n<p>“Electronic signatures are now at the tipping point where it should be expected as part of a broader solution, and not a separate add on. A solution that supports a deal before, during, and after the signature with document workflows, insights, speed, and the end-user experience,” added Mikado. “We’re finding that the market agrees. While we’ve provided this free option, it’s become a lead magnet for us and is helping to accelerate the company’s growth plans for the future.”</p>\n<h3><b>Optimized solutions for the remote work arena</b></h3>\n<p>As with many technology companies set up for optimizing remote working, the company has experienced significant growth through the COVID-19 crisis. However, the company believes this shift in digital transformation, and the need for all-in-one workflow solutions has been a long time in the making and will continue long past the pandemic.</p>\n<p>“The pandemic has certainly accelerated the growth and adoption of document workflow management, but the future of business generally, and sales specifically, is headed in this direction. Once a company realizes there is an easier way to manage documents, contracts, and proposals, from creation to edits to signings to paying, there’s no turning back,” said Mikado.</p>\n<h3><b> HIPAA and FERPA compliant </b></h3>\n<p>While the company’s focus continues to be on helping sales and revenue teams of all sizes, it’s already seen growth in new verticals. Helping to address the growing needs outside of sales, the company has recently achieved both HIPAA and FERPA compliance. The PandaDoc optimum compliance opens the door in the healthcare and education industries providing higher productivity and ease to those most impacted due to the global health crisis.</p>\n<p>While eSignatures have, for years, been an increasingly important part of doing business, it’s clear the pandemic has accelerated the need for straightforward, agile solutions.</p>\n<p>Companies need extensive documentation capabilities that are trusted in a crowded market of fundamentally similar products. The overall digital transformation starts now, as PandaDoc applies new inroads into faster workflows in their solutions for the industries, company eSignatures.</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/08/10/pandadoc-raises-30m-to-lead-a-paradigm-shift-in-esignature-market/\">PandaDoc Raises $30M to Lead a Paradigm Shift in eSignature Market</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 10 Aug 2020 17:02:44 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/PandaDoc-Raises-30M-to-Lead-a-Paradigm-Shift-in-eSignature-Market.jpg","linkMd5":"c1cf24887e377e25909918391d52b1ce","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn28@2020_1/2020/08/23/15-18-24-938_38cda00f64c09262.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/PandaDoc-Raises-30M-to-Lead-a-Paradigm-Shift-in-eSignature-Market.jpg","destWidth":1280,"destHeight":853,"sourceBytes":86625,"destBytes":44424,"author":"Brad Anderson","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/PandaDoc-Raises-30M-to-Lead-a-Paradigm-Shift-in-eSignature-Market-300x200.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn35@2020_1/2020/08/23/15-18-11-006_d86e220bd03a2fa4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195868862},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:53","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:53","title":"A CEO’s Perspective on Net Promoter Score","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=170058","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/07/11/a-ceos-perspective-on-net-promoter-score/\" title=\"A CEO&#8217;s Perspective on Net Promoter Score\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"185\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/A-CEOs-Perspective-on-Net-Promoter-Score-300x185.jpg\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"net promoter score\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/A-CEOs-Perspective-on-Net-Promoter-Score-300x185.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/A-CEOs-Perspective-on-Net-Promoter-Score-260x160.jpg 260w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/A-CEOs-Perspective-on-Net-Promoter-Score.jpg 825w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></div><p>What differentiates a great business from a good business is the power of <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/10/12/improving-customer-loyalty-with-3-easy-steps/\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">customer loyalty</a> and customer satisfaction. A great CEO understands how a satisfied and <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/09/13/how-connected-communities-can-bolster-your-business/\">loyal customer can accelerate business</a> expansion. They have transformed their companies into industry leaders by building loyal relationships with their customers and employees. They have used a magic metric the Net Promoter Score. To understand where their business is lagging and improved on it.</p>\n<p>A CEO creates a benchmark for its organization and makes sure the brand promise is delivered.</p>\n<h2>Net Promoter Score</h2>\n<p>The Net Promoter Score is a simple business metric that gauges how well you are meeting your customers’ expectations. It offers a powerful lens into what customers think about your business and reveals what is wrong.</p>\n<p>NPS is a robust and powerful solution to boost word-of-mouth marketing, increase customer satisfaction, <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/03/18/5-proven-strategies-to-reduce-customer-churn-rate/\">reduce customer churn</a>, and offer <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/10/21/a-better-customer-experience-why-little-things-matter/\">better customer experience</a>.</p>\n<h2>The Three Categories of the Customers</h2>\n<p>The Net Promoter Score survey aims to ask one question to all its audience. ‘On the scale 0 to 10, how likely are you to recommend our company to your friends and family?’ and based on its answers, it measures the customer loyalty of your business.</p>\n<p>Also, based on their scores, the customers are divided into three categories. That is, Promoters, Passives, and Detractors.</p>\n<p><strong>Promoters:</strong> They are the customers who gave a score of 9 or 10. They love your brand’s products and services and are the most loyal customers.<br />\n<strong>Passives:</strong> They are the customers who gave a score of 7 or 8. They are satisfied with your brand’s products or services but can switch to your competitor for a better offer.<br />\n<strong>Detractors:</strong> They are the customers who gave a score of 6 or below. They are not happy with your brand’s services and/or products and are most likely not willing to purchase from you again.</p>\n<h2>How do you calculate NPS?</h2>\n<p>Your company’s Net Promoter Score (surveysensum.com) can be calculated by simply subtracting the percentage of <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/07/03/why-you-should-measure-net-promoter-score-nps/\">Detractors from the percentage of Promoters</a>.</p>\n<p><strong>NPS (Net Promoter Score) = % Promoters &#8211; % Detractors</strong></p>\n<h2>How can NPS Data help your Business?</h2>\n<p>The Net Promoter Score is an effective way to run a business. At the same time, many business leaders are skeptical about the effectiveness of NPS. Numerous studies have shown that high NPS can be directly linked to the growth of the company.</p>\n<p>Here are the 5 crucial points about NPS data with industry leaders’ case studies that any business owner must know.</p>\n<h3>Reduction in Support Costs</h3>\n<p>The Net Promoter Score helps in <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/03/27/how-tech-can-help-your-business-do-more-with-less/\">reducing the business costs</a> by identifying the pain areas of the customers, enabling the Support team to serve the customers better.</p>\n<p>This results in a reduction in call times, improvement in satisfaction score, and an increase in the average number of calls handled at a time, which reduces the support costs of any business by a significant amount.</p>\n<p>Symantec provides cybersecurity software to <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/05/29/the-biggest-cybersecurity-mistakes-businesses-are-still-making/\">protect infrastructure networks</a>, data, and communication. Along with security measures,</p>\n<p>they also address any compliance, availability or performance risks. After adopting NPS in 2004, there has been a <em>50% increase in their product lines, a 30% reduction</em> in support costs, and a significant increase in the number of positive reviews.</p>\n<h3>Increased interaction with Current and Prospective Customers</h3>\n<p>The NPS is a simple metric to track your position in the market. But what is significant is asking the right questions. Often small things have the most significant impact on the NPS, and it is by talking to your customers that you will understand the reasons behind brand loyalty.</p>\n<p>Slack is a business communication platform that brings the communication of all the teams of a business on a single platform. Slack Team used the NPS to answer one question ‘Why should people recommend or not recommend your brand?’</p>\n<p>They refined all the interaction with the current and prospective clients and tracked their progress with the Net Promoter Score, which resulted in a <a href=\"http://fortune.com/2015/01/22/slack-unicorn/\">$1 billion valuation</a> in one year through positive promotions tracked by NPS.</p>\n<h3>Work on the Detractors</h3>\n<p>After a Net Promoter Score survey, it is important to work on the Detractors of your business as their feedback offers an opportunity to improve your business and by analyzing their feedback with actionable insights.</p>\n<p>You can fix some of your problems quickly or take a required action to improve your services or products.</p>\n<p>Apple retail store managers, post their NPS survey, reached out to all of their detractors or dissatisfied customers within 24 hours and analyzed the purchase patterns of the detractors who spoke to store managers and who had not.</p>\n<p>This survey resulted in additional revenue of more than $1,000 or $25 million in a year.</p>\n<h3>Work towards profitability</h3>\n<p><a href=\"https://hbr.org/2003/12/the-one-number-you-need-to-grow\">In the Harvard Business Review,</a> it has been observed that the companies adopting the Net Promoter Score tend to grow twice the rate of their competitors than those who have not adopted NPS.</p>\n<p>It has been recognized that businesses working on their NPS analysis have sustainable, profitable growth, which begins with creating more promoters and fewer detractors.</p>\n<p>Philips Electronics used the NPS for a few of its accounts for some time and observed where the NPS increased. <em>The revenue grew by 69%,</em> where the NPS didn’t change, <em>the revenue grew by 6% only</em>, and where the NPS was not adopted, <em>the revenue decreased by 24%.</em></p>\n<h3>Reduce your Customer Churn</h3>\n<p><a href=\"http://www.netpromotersystem.com/speaking-engagements/fred-reichheld.aspx\">Fred Reichheld created</a> the Net Promoter Score (NPS) to measure the customer’s brand loyalty. The NPS measures customer experience and the likelihood of repeat business. Also, it is the only metric that evaluates the customer churn that helps in working against the inevitable failure.</p>\n<p>Australian Based telecommunication company, Optus, posted a net profit of $227 million during the last quarter of 2013.</p>\n<p>According to the Australian Business Review, the Country Chief Officer Kevin Russell has said that after they adopted the NPS in 2013, there has been a six-point increase in their Net Promoter Score over the December quarter. That was a 50% decrease in the customer complaint,s which resulted in a 41% increase against the last quarter of 2012.</p>\n<h2>Conclusion</h2>\n<p>The Net Promoter Score is the <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/04/15/how-will-iot-improve-the-way-startups-do-business-in-2020/\">one number that you need to grow</a>. It is a simple, profound, and effective way to <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/03/18/5-proven-strategies-to-reduce-customer-churn-rate/\">reduce customer churn</a>, improve loyalty, and word-of-mouth marketing, which leads to great profits.</p>\n<p>Conducting a survey and gathering data is the first step. The companies that have grown their revenue with the NPS implementations have analyzed this data. And took actions to convert detractors to promoters while improving customer experience.</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/07/11/a-ceos-perspective-on-net-promoter-score/\">A CEO&#8217;s Perspective on Net Promoter Score</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 11 Jul 2020 15:01:06 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/A-CEOs-Perspective-on-Net-Promoter-Score.jpg","linkMd5":"2464b0146aca43856547135b33b0c480","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn64@2020_4/2020/08/23/15-18-26-826_9b788f4220b403cc.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/A-CEOs-Perspective-on-Net-Promoter-Score.jpg","destWidth":825,"destHeight":510,"sourceBytes":30775,"destBytes":18578,"author":"Tanuj Diwan","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/A-CEOs-Perspective-on-Net-Promoter-Score-300x185.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn84@2020_4/2020/08/23/15-18-11-495_fe60c97286e2120c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195873189},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:18:00","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:18:00","title":"How to Apply IoT in the Oil and Gas Industry","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=161573","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/02/23/how-to-apply-iot-in-the-oil-and-gas-industry/\" title=\"How to Apply IoT in the Oil and Gas Industry\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"200\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/How-to-Apply-IoT-in-the-Oil-and-Gas-Industry-1-1-300x200.jpg\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"iot in oil and gas\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/How-to-Apply-IoT-in-the-Oil-and-Gas-Industry-1-1-300x200.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/How-to-Apply-IoT-in-the-Oil-and-Gas-Industry-1-1-900x600.jpg 900w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/How-to-Apply-IoT-in-the-Oil-and-Gas-Industry-1-1-240x160.jpg 240w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/How-to-Apply-IoT-in-the-Oil-and-Gas-Industry-1-1-1536x1024.jpg 1536w,
