However, COVID-19 is not a typical outbreak. The virus is often transmitted by individuals who display no symptoms of the infection and may not even realize that they are carrying the virus.</p>\n<p>Standard contact tracing usually involves individuals who are symptomatic and are aware they are carrying the infection in question. Because of this, traditional contact tracing methods are challenging and problematic.</p>\n<p>The Big Data Institute at Oxford University has proposed a <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/07/24/is-there-any-stopping-techs-big-four-from-monopolizing-user-data/\">solution for a mobile contact tracing application</a> that is much more agile, efficient, and scalable than traditional manual contact tracing methods. The team developed a <a href=\"https://045.medsci.ox.ac.uk/Epidemiology\">mathematical model</a> designed to stop the epidemic if implemented on mobile devices by a substantial portion of the population. It’s poised to reduce manual contact tracing from 72 hours to four hours. By replacing weeks worth of manual work performing contact tracing, the mobile application can slow the spread much more quickly than traditional methods.</p>\n<h3>For the proposed mobile tracing method to be effective, quite a few hurdles must be overcome.</h3>\n<p>First, the majority of the population – including symptomatic and asymptomatic individuals – must voluntarily opt-in and adopt the application. The research team at Oxford estimates that about 60% of the population would have to utilize the application for mobile tracing to reach enough new virus cases to make an impact on the spread of the virus.</p>\n<p>Another challenge lies in widespread and accessible COVID-19 testing. For the application to work, the majority of the population would need to have access to reliable testing in order for the application to properly and fully survey potential outbreaks.</p>\n<p>There is much evidence suggesting that the application of rigorous wide-scale testing coupled with the application of mobile technology can blunt COVID-19 infection and mortality rates.</p>\n<h3>Taiwan was able to contain the COVID-19 outbreak better. Why?</h3>\n<p>A recent Stanford <a href=\"https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2762689\">report</a> demonstrates how Taiwan – a country just 130 km from the epicenter of the outbreak in China – was able to contain the outbreak without the draconian lockdown measures in place throughout many of the advanced economies.</p>\n<p>How did Taiwan manage to limit and contain the spread of the virus? The report highlights five interconnected factors: pandemic readiness, national electronic health records database, wide-scale testing, big data analytics, and the use of <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/06/17/how-can-blockchain-help-secure-iot-data/\">mobile technology to track movements of individuals</a> who tested positive for COVID-19.</p>\n<p>Within 72 hours of the outbreak, a comprehensive case identification protocol was instituted based on travel histories. Individuals determined to be high risk were monitored through their mobile devices.</p>\n<p>Health authorities were then able to trace the movements of high-risk subjects and mitigate the risk of further transmission through targeted isolation measures. Taiwan may serve as a template for how to mitigate future pandemics.</p>\n<h2><strong>Balancing public interest and data privacy rights. </strong></h2>\n<p>Innovative initiatives are underway by major tech companies, notably Google, Apple, and Facebook, to track and analyze how the virus is spreading and to gauge the effectiveness of social distancing measures.</p>\n<p>Facebook’s <a href=\"https://dataforgood.fb.com/tools/disease-prevention-maps/\">Data for Good</a> project is designed to track the movements of users to measure and anticipate potential outbreaks.</p>\n<p>In the context of the COVID-19 outbreak, researchers, non-profits and public agencies can leverage the data – which is anonymized and aggregated – to evaluate and implement strategies to slow the spread. However, such initiatives raise concerns about transparency and <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/04/30/big-data-as-a-double-edged-sword-in-the-fight-against-covid-19/\">data privacy</a> rights.</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Data-Privacy-and-Coronavirus.jpg\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-171134 size-large\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Data-Privacy-and-Coronavirus-900x675.jpg\" alt=\"Data Privacy, Technology\" width=\"900\" height=\"675\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Data-Privacy-and-Coronavirus-900x675.jpg 900w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Data-Privacy-and-Coronavirus-300x225.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Data-Privacy-and-Coronavirus-213x160.jpg 213w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Data-Privacy-and-Coronavirus-1536x1152.jpg 1536w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Data-Privacy-and-Coronavirus.jpg 1920w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px\" /></a></p>\n<p>There’s a strong case to be made that the implementation of mobile tracking applications represents an unwelcome intrusion to privacy rights.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>The Washington Post reports that <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/cellphone-monitoring-is-spreading-with-the-coronavirus-so-is-an-uneasy-tolerance-of-surveillance/2020/05/02/56f14466-7b55-11ea-a311-adb1344719a9_story.html\">three out of five Americans</a> are either unwilling or unable to use the infection alert system that is being created <a href=\"https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2020/04/apple-and-google-partner-on-covid-19-contact-tracing-technology/?subId3=xid:fr1587465086697agi\">by Apple and Google</a>.</li>\n<li>In certain contexts, however, there are some legal grounds for this type of mobile tracing.</li>\n<li>The <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2017/09/16/gdpr-european-union-business-dl1/\">General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)</a> identifies <a href=\"https://gdpr-info.eu/art-6-gdpr/\">six grounds</a> for lawful processing of personally identifiable information (PII).</li>\n</ul>\n<h4>When the processing of PII is necessary for the public interest, then it can be done without obtaining the data subject’s consent.</h4>\n<p>The GDPR includes specific guidelines for the use of data in the context of epidemics. Recital <a href=\"https://www.privacy-regulation.eu/en/recital-46-GDPR.htm\">46 of GDPR </a> stipulates that the collection and processing of personally identifiable information without data subject consent are acceptable when it is necessary for humanitarian purposes. The information includes monitoring the spread of epidemics and addressing humanitarian emergencies, such as natural or man-made disasters.</p>\n<h2><strong>Tips for the transparent and ethical use of technology.</strong></h2>\n<p>It is the responsibility of technology leaders and policymakers to implement ethically sound, transparent, and fair applications related to the use of AI-driven profiling technologies and the transmission of highly sensitive health information.</p>\n<p>For mobile tracing applications to be widely adopted and therefore effective in slowing the spread of COVID-19, the first and most important step is the grain the public’s trust.</p>\n<p>Principles of fairness and transparency related to <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/04/27/covid-19-jobs-data-and-machine-learning/\">artificial intelligence</a> are re-enforced by the EU Commission on The Ethics Guidelines for Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence. Every organization should be committed to these seven fundamental guiding principles for the application of AI technologies:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Human agency and oversight</li>\n<li>Technical robustness and safety</li>\n<li>Privacy and data governance</li>\n<li>Transparency</li>\n<li>Diversity, non-discrimination and fairness</li>\n<li>Societal and environmental well-being</li>\n<li>Accountability</li>\n</ol>\n<p>These principles were further re-enforced by AI Now Institute in its <a href=\"https://ainowinstitute.org/aiareport2018.pdf\">2018 report</a> in which the organization asserted the importance of the public’s right to known which technology systems are impacting their everyday lives and how they are doing so. To that end, organizations must be transparent of the algorithmic systems used and their purpose, applications, and potential public impact.</p>\n<p>Furthermore, while the use of technologies to help mitigate the impact of COVID-19 may be essential to protect public health and safety, they should meet the following criteria as proposed by the Electronic Frontier Foundation:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>The use of such technology must be medically necessary, as determined by appropriate public health experts.</li>\n<li>New processing of personal data should be in proportion to actual needs.</li>\n<li>The use of such technology must be non-discriminatory and without bias; people must not be scrutinized due to nationality or other demographics.</li>\n<li>Any new government powers that have arisen due to new measures must expire once the disease is contained.</li>\n</ul>\n<h4>Innovative technologies have the potential to accelerate and transform efforts to combat the spread of the novel coronavirus.</h4>\n<p>In order for these solutions to fulfill their intended objective and have the greatest positive impact, transparency and fairness are needed.</p>\n<p>Before the public adopts new technologies at scale, they must trust these new and emerging innovations. The ethical use of AI should be evaluated not only on a legal basis but on a moral one as well.</p>\n<p>It’s the only way for novel solutions to gain the people’s trust, inspire widespread adoption, and make the greatest impact – in times of crisis and in the post-COVID-19 world.</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/06/22/how-to-ensure-data-privacy-in-the-time-of-coronavirus/\">How to Ensure Data Privacy in the Time of Coronavirus</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 22 Jun 2020 15:01:07 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/How-to-Ensure-Data-Privacy-in-the-Time-of-Coronavirus.jpg","linkMd5":"0adaa59b4e69c1e7ec102014bd1aaa27","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn73@2020_3/2020/08/23/15-18-10-728_490339a99e91d9a4.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/How-to-Ensure-Data-Privacy-in-the-Time-of-Coronavirus.jpg","destWidth":1920,"destHeight":1280,"sourceBytes":326877,"destBytes":241926,"author":"Bruce Orcutt","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/How-to-Ensure-Data-Privacy-in-the-Time-of-Coronavirus-300x200.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn64@2020_3/2020/08/23/15-18-28-480_bc24de35db58d2ca.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Data-Privacy-and-Coronavirus-900x675.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn87@2020_6/2020/08/23/15-18-12-186_06b56f9a4decf0e7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195875138},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:18:02","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:18:02","title":"How to Send the Warmest Cold Emails","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=164977","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/02/14/how-to-send-the-warmest-cold-emails/\" title=\"How to Send the Warmest Cold Emails\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"197\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/How-to-Send-the-Warmest-Cold-Emails-300x197.jpg\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"cold emails\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/How-to-Send-the-Warmest-Cold-Emails-300x197.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/How-to-Send-the-Warmest-Cold-Emails-900x591.jpg 900w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/How-to-Send-the-Warmest-Cold-Emails-244x160.jpg 244w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/How-to-Send-the-Warmest-Cold-Emails-1536x1008.jpg 1536w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/How-to-Send-the-Warmest-Cold-Emails.jpg 1920w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></div><p>Emails (cold emails or newsletters or transactional emails or whatever you use) are a medium that is as powerful as ever. With more than <b>3.8 million</b> email users (the number is expected to surpass 4.2 million by 2023), and <b>more than two email addresses</b> per user &#8212; it’s safe to say that email is (or can be) a marketing goldmine. Here is how to send the warmest cold emails ever.</p>\n<h3>Nowadays, email has almost completely replaced your home address.</h3>\n<p>It hasn’t completely succeeded in the obliteration of a home address &#8212; only because physical orders cannot possibly appear in our inbox in digital form although that would be nice.</p>\n<p><figure id=\"attachment_164978\" aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-164978\" style=\"width: 713px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><a href=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image1.png\"><img class=\"wp-image-164978 size-full\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image1.png\" alt=\"email usage\" width=\"713\" height=\"518\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image1.png 713w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image1-300x218.png 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image1-220x160.png 220w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 713px) 100vw, 713px\" /></a><figcaption id=\"caption-attachment-164978\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><em><strong>Statistics of how many people use email.</strong></em></figcaption></figure></p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">(<a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/255080/number-of-e-mail-users-worldwide/\">Source</a>)</p>\n<h3>Keep these things in mind with your cold emails.</h3>\n<ul>\n<li>  <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2018/06/13/why-i-choose-email-marketing-for-best-roi/\"><i>“Email campaigns [&#8230;] have been found to increase revenues by 760% on average,”</i></a> more than most brands have tried and keep trying to modify their marketing game in a way that will drive <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/01/06/successful-scaling-how-to-grow-without-tumbling-back-down/\">growth</a> through email marketing and marketing automation in all its forms.</li>\n<li>There is a need for platforms like Moosend-one of the biggest Constant Contact competitors-comes into play.</li>\n<li>Brands are trying to grow in a way that will help them stand out from the crowd.</li>\n<li>Also, brands are becoming more or less a household name, like Nike or Amazon.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>One of the most profitable things you can use, in order to see your conversion skyrocket is something <em>all of us</em> have demonized in our heads:</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><b>Sending out cold emails.</b></h3>\n<p>Of course, I am not talking about those email blasts from the past or those random, spammy-looking emails we all receive from time to time:</p>\n<p><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-164986 size-full\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image9.png\" alt=\"cold email spam email\" width=\"748\" height=\"357\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image9.png 748w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image9-300x143.png 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image9-260x124.png 260w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 748px) 100vw, 748px\" /></p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">(<a href=\"https://www.ezcomputersolutions.com/blog/hilarious-spam-email-examples/\">Source</a>)</p>\n<p>Hyper-personalized “cold” emails with stellar email personalization are what I’m talking about and what I think needs to be a staple in any and all <a href=\"https://venngage.com/blog/marketing-plan/\">marketing plans</a>.</p>\n<p>There are specific rules to follow, before sending cold emails.</p>\n<h2><strong>Research is key.</strong></h2>\n<p>Maybe you’re the best at promoting yourself and your services. Maybe your brand knows what it’s doing when it comes to your product.</p>\n<h4><strong>How is your email going to depict these facts in a way that will be relevant, timely, and appropriate?</strong></h4>\n<p>Go ahead and do your research. Sign up for your competitors’ newsletter campaigns and expect some cold emails from them as well. Then, start studying your findings.</p>\n<p>Studying your findings will help you determine what kind of needs your cold email campaign needs to cover. The findings will also help with project management. Your cold email campaign is a project in and of itself, that will help you out with other projects.</p>\n<p>However, researching the competition is not the only thing you’ll need to do in this case.</p>\n<h2><strong>Who is your ideal customer?</strong></h2>\n<p>To know who would love to hear from you &#8212; you’ll need to create your buyer personas.</p>\n<p>Buyer personas are depictions of what your ideal customer should be like. From their educational level, down to their location on the globe, buyer personas can provide a whole lot of insights and usually work like a charm:</p>\n<p><figure id=\"attachment_164987\" aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-164987\" style=\"width: 702px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><a href=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image10.png\"><img class=\"wp-image-164987 size-full\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image10.png\" alt=\"buyer persona\" width=\"702\" height=\"471\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image10.png 702w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image10-300x201.png 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image10-238x160.png 238w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 702px) 100vw, 702px\" /></a><figcaption id=\"caption-attachment-164987\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><em><strong>Showing the buyer persona power for cold emails.</strong></em></figcaption></figure></p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">(<a href=\"https://medium.com/swlh/craft-your-persona-like-trump-daca6b44d770\">Source</a>)</p>\n<p>Buyer personas worked perfectly in generating leads and exceeding expectations. The buyer persona can answer your key questions:</p>\n<ol>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Who would be <b>interested </b>in your product?</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Who would find <b>benefit </b>from your product?</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Could these people end up <b>buying </b>your product?</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Could they end up buying <b>more than once</b>?</li>\n</ol>\n<p>Let’s assume that you’re selling link building packages. It’s a very specific product that wouldn’t interest someone that’s not a marketer or a brand that is using growth strategies.</p>\n<h2><strong>Are subject lines important?</strong></h2>\n<p>In short, yes, the subject line is important. But why? And what do you need to do to make sure that you won’t fail?</p>\n<p>A subject line is the very first thing a prospect notices about your email. A failed subject line can do this:</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image8.png\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-164985 size-full\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image8.png\" alt=\"cold emails subject line\" width=\"573\" height=\"624\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image8.png 573w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image8-275x300.png 275w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image8-147x160.png 147w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 573px) 100vw, 573px\" /></a></p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">(<a href=\"https://www.invespcro.com/blog/email-subject-lines-statistics-and-trends/\">Source</a>)</p>\n<p>The last thing you need is someone hurting your deliverability rate and making you appear to be the “bad guy.”</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: left;\"><strong>Here are some examples of subject lines to avoid at all costs:</strong></h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Don’t begin with questions.</strong> “Do you want to save your <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/01/10/visual-merchandising-online-startups-cannot-afford-to-overlookvisual-merchandising-online-startups-cannot-afford-to-overlook/\">average order value</a> from plummeting?” Nah mate, I’d rather not, because the first thing that comes to my mind is that you want me to pay you for something. And asking for money through a cold email <b>screams</b> spam. You can find an alternative way of saying this, such as: “Your customer feedback strategy is on point, congrats [name]”</li>\n<li><strong>Grammar, punctuation</strong>, and the number of words and keywords are too important: Poor grammar <b>is</b> spam, and too many exclamation points make your subject line look like spam to Google-and look tacky. What is more, the number of words is something that can make or break your open rate.You’ll get the best response at an open rate if you’ve got a subject line that’s somewhere between 6-10 words. Lastly, <b>avoid too many keywords</b>. It looks robotic, feels rushed and guess what it can do for your cold email campaign. You’re right, nothing.</li>\n<li><strong>Avoid using:</strong> “RE:,” “FWD:,” “URGENT,” and clickbait subject lines. Any of these beginnings will not resonate well with your recipients. Let me explain why: <strong>“RE:”</strong> shows that you’ve no idea who you’re emailing &#8212; or that you’re a bot. Either way, since the prospect never sent something for you to reply to &#8212; straight to the spam folder you go.“FWD:” seems more than a little unprofessional. Your prospect will consider that you didn’t take the time to erase the word “FWD” from the subject line. Imagine where your email will end up if your prospect thinks, “I never asked to be sent anything in the first place, and I don’t know that person.”\n<p>As for <strong>the “URGENT,”</strong> I think it’s more than obvious. Inconsistent, bullshit or misleading subject lines will lead your email to the spam folder and send your deliverability rate to a downward spiral.</li>\n</ul>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">Craft your subject line in a manner that won’t reveal too much information.</h3>\n<p>Opting for clickbait? Crafting your subject line will increase your open rate, sure, but that’s about it.</p>\n<p>I&#8217;m critical of the overly spammy subject line techniques that resurface every now and then. Don&#8217;t get anxiety; here is a thing or two about what makes a successful subject line.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>\n<h4><strong>Let your prospects decide whether they’d like to open your email or not.</strong></h4>\n</li>\n<li>For them to be able to decide to click or not to click &#8212; you need to be clear on what your email is about.</li>\n<li>Being clear does <b>not</b> mean you need to give them any available information.</li>\n<li>Be clear but playful:</li>\n</ul>\n<p><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-164983 size-full\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image6.png\" alt=\"sales email newsletter kat von d\" width=\"842\" height=\"40\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image6.png 842w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image6-300x14.png 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image6-260x12.png 260w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 842px) 100vw, 842px\" /></p>\n<p><strong>The above subject line comes from my personal inbox and is the perfect example of what I’m trying to say.</strong></p>\n<p>For example How many hours are left “a few hours?” I need to open the email to get the answer.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Write something opinionated. For example, “Video conferencing is the only way to hold conferences” or “Festive marketing is dead.”</li>\n<li><strong>Remember this truth:</strong> The truth is that an opinionated subject line may not attract all of the crowd, but it will attract the right crowd. The <strong>right crowd</strong> is who you&#8217;re looking for with cold email.</li>\n</ul>\n<h4>Utilize the Fear Of Missing Out (FOMO). You can create urgency:</h4>\n<p><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-164979 size-full\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image2.png\" alt=\"fomo cold email\" width=\"514\" height=\"66\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image2.png 514w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image2-300x39.png 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image2-260x33.png 260w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 514px) 100vw, 514px\" /></p>\n<ul>\n<li>With this FOMO &#8212; I fell into the trap, as expected.</li>\n<li>I saw something I couldn’t refuse &#8212; which was the offer.</li>\n<li>I also saw something that made me think that the offer’s gone.</li>\n<li>I <strong>had</strong> to click on the site and see what the offer was &#8212; and so will your customers.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2>The body copy of your email.</h2>\n<p>Let’s assume that the prospect loved your subject line and opened your email. That’s great; you managed to stand out in a full inbox. But how are you going to keep your prospects’ attention intact? One of your choices would be to use something other than words to attract just the right amount of attention without being overbearing.</p>\n<p>You can achieve this by adding pictures and GIFs to your email’s body copy.</p>\n<p>Let’s assume that you’re a band that has just released a new track. Instead of sending an email with the announcement, you can use video email marketing or send a <a href=\"https://www.spotify.com/\">Spotify</a> type email with a picture of the album you’re referring to. Let your fans go about music streaming by just pressing a CTA button.</p>\n<h3>Have you studies your buyer persona?</h3>\n<p>Maybe your ideal customer likes text better because they’re old-fashioned like that? Your prospects are not reading your emails because they love reading. They’re reading your email because it provides a solution.</p>\n<p>As an example: Let’s say that you’ve got a blog post ready. The blog post talks about making money with affiliate marketing. Do you think that sending an announcement about your new blog post will make people want to read it?</p>\n<p>Of course not. But providing a snippet or a part of the solution you’re going to talk about, that will lead customers to the result they want.</p>\n<h3>If you want to make sure that you find an easy benefit that people will want, propose as a solution, something like starting an online business.</h3>\n<p>You can provide this solution by doing extensive research on your competitors’ <b>bad </b>reviews and then propose a solution already proposed by the consumers themselves. After all, buyers consider products that can turn them into the best version of themselves.</p>\n<p>If you apply the principle to business owners looking at a product, you&#8217;ll see that they are looking at the best version of their business and not a product itself.</p>\n<p>For example, if you’ve got a brick-and-mortar store, you’ll need to make your online presence known as well. 39% of customers visit a brand&#8217;s website before they purchase in a physical store. 9.6% of GenZ shoppers report buying items in a physical store, compared to Millennials.</p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p>What could that mean, other than needing an eCommerce website builder? Something like that will be the optimal solution for your store, as well as a full eCommerce inventory guide.</p>\n<p>Best tip: Keep your message short and sweet. The readers won’t bother with lengthy text. If you need to showcase a demo of “the solution” you’re proposing, make it through a video.</p>\n<p>Your readers need to see the value of your cold email-and, by extension, the solution you’re trying to provide &#8212; upfront &#8212; don’t make them look for it. Usually, just a couple of sentences are more than enough.</p>\n<h2>Did you personalize at all?</h2>\n<p>Personalization goes way beyond just the first name on the subject line. You’ll need to compose tailor-made messages that will suit your prospects’ needs. And this is where segmentation comes into play.</p>\n<p>Let’s assume that you need to segment your list to the following categories: CEO, CFO, and employee.</p>\n<p>It’s easy enough to find with a little digging on the internet. Just make sure you’re using your data correctly. An employee that has just been promoted to CFO won’t appreciate the downgrade and, most likely, won’t go through with the email.</p>\n<h4>You need a different benefit of the product for all the different positions of your customers&#8217; persona.</h4>\n<p>If you’re about to talk to the Head of Sales of the company, you can provide a sales-y solution to making more money. Promote a digital customer loyalty program that will retain their recurring digital customers by offering sales and benefits, thus increasing their ARR.</p>\n<p>If, on the other hand, you’re about to talk to the CMO, make sure to let them know about the best SEO companies that can help them increase in growth for their marketing department’s SEO game. Of course, you can’t go ahead with that kind of hyper-personalization for every cold email campaign you’re going to be sending out &#8212; but you get the gist.</p>\n<p>If you’re dealing with very high-quality prospects, it’s worth the effort and the time, as it will look like you’re here to provide real solutions and that you’ve spent more than five minutes on research, rather than just wanting to score a quick sale.</p>\n<h2>Why should people trust you?</h2>\n<p>Are you looking here for answers to your questions &#8212; and not to answer someone else&#8217;s problems?</p>\n<h3>Answer these questions.</h3>\n<ul>\n<li>What makes you one-of-a-kind in your field?</li>\n<li>What makes you a person that people can trust or look up to?</li>\n<li>Why should people listen to you?</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Capture your prospects’ attention by introducing yourself right from the beginning. Tell them why you are essential. Use a description that will build credibility. Your description could be a little sentence or a link to your social media profiles.</p>\n<p>If you’re an influencer, you can send a cold email that will be showcasing your tips. Can you show this customer how to be featured in social media influencers’ posts? Can you actually help people out?</p>\n<h4>With your tips and information, you will build credibility throughout the whole email.</h4>\n<p>The reason you need to build that credibility is straightforward: You need people to take the time and not just open your email, but actually read it. You want them to know that they can click on the links or CTA buttons, and they will achieve value. You help them achieve conversion rate optimization.</p>\n<p>The second reason you need to use your “trust badges,” would be to increase your engagement levels. Engagement levels mean that you are getting actual <b>responses </b>from your prospects.</p>\n<h2>Your CTA is essential.</h2>\n<p>Your CTA plays a <b>considerable</b> <b>part</b> in your success &#8212; from its look, down to the wording.</p>\n<p>The subject line and body copy should be precise, but just a little cryptic. Your CTA, on the other hand, needs to be super clear on the action your prospect needs to take. That way, you will reach your end goal.</p>\n<h4>No customer wants a hard sell.</h4>\n<p>While a customer may work in person or on the phone &#8212; it’s a lot easier to delete a cold email. Avoid selling &#8212; or even asking for a meeting &#8212; in your first email. <strong>Remember</strong>: you’re not going to sell on that first email &#8212; and perhaps not even on the second one.</p>\n<h4>Use the first email as an introduction or to build a relationship.</h4>\n<p>But be careful with what you’re trying to do.</p>\n<p>Instead of a sell, you could call your prospects to act on a straightforward step. “Check our guide,” or “Download our free eBook.”</p>\n<h4>Encourage your prospects to share your cold email with their friends or other employees.</h4>\n<p>If you include some referrals’ discount or exclusive benefit in your email, it would work like a charm and would reduce your <a href=\"https://www.profitwell.com/blog/saas-metrics-calculate-and-optimize-saas-mrr-churn\">MRR churn</a>, seeing as you’d always have new leads coming about without spending extra budget money to obtain them.</p>\n<p><b>Pro tip: </b>You can also go ahead and read all about the referral marketing definition and how it affects all businesses before trying it out on your own.</p>\n<p>Also, remember to use contrasting colors for your CTA buttons.</p>\n<h3>If there is no CTA button, <b>use bold letters</b>.</h3>\n<p>You should draw their attention, using contrasting colors. Make sure that they won’t miss your last message: What it is that they’re supposed to do.</p>\n<h2>Don’t forget to follow up</h2>\n<p>Your prospect took the time to read your email despite never having heard of you. They also took the time to see the value and, eventually, took the time to convert.</p>\n<p>You should at least send them a follow-up email to see how they enjoyed your product. This practice will lead your new (for now) leads further down the funnel and will eventually turn your customers into recurring customers.</p>\n<p>You can also follow-up if they haven’t responded to your email, thus earning yourself a second chance at engagement.</p>\n<p><b>Hint:</b> Most reply to those emails, so it would be a real shame not to utilize a follow-up.</p>\n<h3>One final thought</h3>\n<p>The last thing I’d like to share with you as a tip is something that you already know &#8212; but please do this.</p>\n<h4><b>Always</b> A/B test, my children, always A/B test.</h4>\n<p>Testing will lead to your best optimization, and will definitely, growth-hack your cold email game.</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/02/14/how-to-send-the-warmest-cold-emails/\">How to Send the Warmest Cold Emails</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 15 Feb 2020 00:00:53 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/How-to-Send-the-Warmest-Cold-Emails.jpg","linkMd5":"5005215ff84cb48f666929fc4d9d6065","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn71@2020_5/2020/08/23/15-18-09-748_a512dcea1d6474c4.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/How-to-Send-the-Warmest-Cold-Emails.jpg","destWidth":1920,"destHeight":1260,"sourceBytes":551866,"destBytes":249604,"author":"Tea Liarokapi","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/How-to-Send-the-Warmest-Cold-Emails-300x197.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn51@2020_6/2020/08/23/15-18-14-420_520cf0a8c1b9855d.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn87@2020_5/2020/08/23/15-18-14-549_b2ebd01b0604d6bc.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn67@2020_4/2020/08/23/15-18-11-240_e1c2c46fd30dec5d.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image10.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn19@2020_3/2020/08/23/15-18-12-971_b85514fa6d591aed.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image8.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn32@2020_3/2020/08/23/15-18-11-940_5e3e12f6455f8cc2.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image6.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn19@2020_5/2020/08/23/15-18-13-382_375bef2c98c1f5b3.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/image2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn32@2020_3/2020/08/23/15-18-16-946_88158692bf35b9e7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195882940},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:18:00","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:18:00","title":"Social Media has had its Day","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=166913","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/02/18/social-media-has-had-its-day/\" title=\"Social Media has had its Day\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"185\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Social-Media-has-had-its-Day-300x185.jpeg\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"social media\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Social-Media-has-had-its-Day-300x185.jpeg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Social-Media-has-had-its-Day-260x160.jpeg 260w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Social-Media-has-had-its-Day.jpeg 825w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></div><p><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/01/24/where-does-social-media-think-its-going-now/\">Social media</a> was supposed to be the ultimate free speech platform, a place where the world would come together to swap information and share opinions. It would be the battleground of ideas. Someone would say something that looked sensible, face a challenge from someone with a different experience, and new facts, and the world would move forward with smarter and better thoughts. But the question is: has social media had its day?</p>\n<h2>Social Media hasn’t quite worked out the way we thought it would.</h2>\n<p>Twitter has become a playground for bots and trolls. Facebook is filled with misinformation, a place where foreign governments can set up groups to spread fake news.</p>\n<p>Saying something that isn’t in vogue won’t prompt someone else to say: “Huh, I never thought of it that way.” It’s more likely to produce a giant virtual pile-on that results in boycotts and ostracism. Who knew we were closed-minded? Who knew that no new opinioned could be offered or tried? &#8211;Zero&#8211; and</p>\n<p>The platforms themselves have struggled to cope, <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2019/05/02/facebook-alex-jones-laura-loomer-ban/\">blocking some opinions</a> and taking flak from <a href=\"https://mashable.com/article/facebook-right-wing-social-network/\">one side</a> or <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/story/2019/08/20/facebook-audit-conservative-bias-amid-criticism-1469287\">the other</a>.</p>\n<h2>At the same time, users have retreated into their own bubbles.</h2>\n<p>Instead of coming to Facebook or Twitter to learn something new and obtain a fresh viewpoint, we listen to people who agree with our preconceptions, and misconceptions and who reinforce our prejudices.</p>\n<h2>Knowing we CAN&#8217;T STAND anything new &#8212; we GET nothing new.</h2>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.fastcompany.com/3046111/why-scientists-are-upset-over-the-facebook-filter-bubble-study\">Algorithms</a> feed us more of the same. The constant reminders of why we’re right &#8212; seem to be satisfying to us. But always thinking the same way is not very educated &#8212; and having the same thoughts day in and day out won&#8217;t ever help to break down barriers or improve understanding.</p>\n<h3>Breaking down barriers was one of the big benefits that social media was supposed to deliver.</h3>\n<p>Sure, we can still keep in touch with old friends on Facebook and we can see what everyone is eating for breakfast on Instagram, but as information platforms, social media just isn’t working.</p>\n<h3>You think you are against censorship &#8212; well, you&#8217;re not &#8212; and you&#8217;ve proved it.</h3>\n<p>Brands have noticed that you want the same thing, too. According to one <a href=\"https://www.rivaliq.com/blog/2019-social-media-benchmark-report/\">study</a>, 2019 saw a fall in social media engagement of around 50 percent across a range of industries. People are turning off. We might still open an app and flick through a timeline but we’re less likely to stop and comment or like. Why? Because it&#8217;s the same old thing.</p>\n<h2>So what happens next? If social media has plateaued, what’s likely to replace it?</h2>\n<p>One clue lies in the rise of TikTok. A platform developed in China and subject, at least in part, to Chinese government censorship.</p>\n<p>Censorship might not look like the answer to social media’s free speech problem, but it avoids the issue altogether. It&#8217;s what we&#8217;ve all been forcing on Social Media. Don&#8217;t have any free-thinking thoughts. Don&#8217;t say anything that might break down barriers and build understanding.</p>\n<h4>The content on the TikTok site is generally made up of young people dancing and lip-syncing.</h4>\n<p>Oh goodie! No sharing of dangerous views here where you&#8217;d be challenged. There’s just a sharing of fun and quirky clips that people want to watch and enjoy.</p>\n<p>Social networking as a whole might be under pressure but the media side of social media—the home-made videos spread between friends—that’s still working fine, and it’s likely to continue.</p>\n<h2>One way Social Media sharing will continue is in increased use of live video.</h2>\n<p>In 2018, about one in four Americans listened to at least one podcast every month. In 2019, that number had risen to <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/06/business/media/podcast-growth.html\">one in three</a>. But podcasting is only audio and it only works in one direction.</p>\n<h4>Podcasters broadcast; listeners listen. Live video is also visual, and it’s interactive.</h4>\n<p>Viewers watch and listen, and they can also ask questions and engage with the speakers. Video might not be something you can use while jogging or driving to work, but it’s a lot more engaging than cable TV.</p>\n<h4>As brands find that their posts and pictures are ignored, expect more companies to turn to live engagement.</h4>\n<p>And as users find that they’re getting less back for the data they give, they’ll also be less willing to hand over that data. Why should they tell Facebook what they like, and who they are, and where they live, when Facebook won’t let them say what they think?</p>\n<p>Why give your data and information when it gives everyone a way to abuse you and gives a bash-fest-opening? How long will there be free-speech and free-thinking? &#8230;Not long.</p>\n<h4>We’re already seeing a <a href=\"https://brave.com/\">pushback</a> against data collection by nosy Web browsers.</h4>\n<p>If that giant pushback succeeds, it won’t be long before we start to see rival social media platforms that promise equal levels of privacy &#8212; even if it can’t deliver free-speech</p>\n<h2>These are strange times for social media.</h2>\n<p>On the one hand, the industry has succeeded and grown faster than just about any industry before it. On the other hand, despite being little more than <a href=\"http://sixdegrees.com/\">two decades old</a>, it’s already showing its cracks.</p>\n<p>A fantastic tool that has allowed so many people to talk to each other, entertain each other, and exchange news isn’t going to disappear. But its challenging environment and information bubble will mean that it’s about to evolve in a whole new direction.</p>\n<p>But, will we like it?</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/02/18/social-media-has-had-its-day/\">Social Media has had its Day</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 18 Feb 2020 16:00:42 Recent <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5449130/\">medical</a> reports show that healthy adults who suffer from short-term sleep issues experience increased stress response, pain, reduced quality of life, emotional distress, and mood disorders. Symptoms of long-term sleep disruption are even more alarming; these include an increased risk of developing cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, and certain types of cancer.</p>\n<p>With <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/sleep/index.html\">1 in 3 US adults</a> getting less than adequate sleep, many mattress companies are working hard to provide sleepers with a solution. The integration of new technology is helping many brands address specific sleep concerns. From firmness to temperature, tech provides the tools to create a more advanced and comfortable mattress. recommend the AS3–its medium firmness makes it perfect for side, back, and stomach sleepers. It also comes in a Hybrid version.</i></p>\n<p>Amerisleep’s mattresses provide superior comfort and support. Amerisleep is a brand that understands individual needs vary and what works for one person may not work for another. To make shopping for a mattress as easy as possible, they have designed a line of 5 beds that vary in firmness.</p>\n<p>Based on your body type, preferred sleep position, and comfort needs, you can select <a href=\"https://amerisleep.com/mattresses.html\">one of their 5 mattresses</a>. The AS1 is their firmest mattress, while the AS2 is medium-firm and works well for back and stomach sleepers. Business Insider rates the AS2 “the best mattress for back pain.” The AS3 is their most popular mattress because of its medium firmness. Allure even calls Amerisleep’s AS3 one of the top mattresses to buy online. The firmness level of the AS3 makes it the perfect bed for combination, back, and side sleepers. The AS4 is a medium-soft mattress that features 4 inches of foam in the top layer. This layer makes it ideal for side sleepers who need extra cushioning around the hips and shoulders. Lastly, the AS5 is the softest option and is excellent for heavy sleepers.</p>\n<p>What makes Amerisleep mattresses so advanced? All of their beds feature an open-cell, Certi-PUR certified, plant-based memory foam that is eco-friendly, non-toxic, and breathable. Their covers feature FDA-determined Celliant technology, which is clinically proven to increase local blood flow and recovery. This unique material converts body heat into infrared light to encourage deeper sleep and faster healing. HIVE technology provides pressure-relieving support and spinal alignment. The unique construction offers a firmer feel and added comfort around the torso and hips. Around the areas where pressure points tend to develop, it allows for deeper compression and cushion.</p>\n<p>In addition to their state-of-the-art mattresses, they offer the <a href=\"https://amerisleep.com/adjustable-bed-gold-package.html\">Amerisleep Adjustable Bed</a>. This adjustable base allows you to change the angle of your head and feet through a wireless remote or in-app controls. In addition to head and foot articulation, the pillow tilting feature lets you angle your head so you can read or journal in bed. The controls come with Bluetooth compatibility so you can link to a smart home system too. Also, a preset button makes it easy to find your favorite position again and again. A “snore” button can help you quickly raise the upper portion of the bed to open up airways, and the “flat” button can take you from your preferred sleep position to a flat position with just the click of a button.</p>\n<p>This base features 8 USB ports so you can plug in your devices without the use of unsightly power strips, and the WallHugger technology means that you never have to stretch or strain to reach your nightstand. As the bed rises, the MicroHook retention system prevents the mattress from sliding or moving. A strip of tiny, gentle velcro located near the foot of the mattress keeps it firmly in place. Additionally, the adjustable legs that come with the Amerisleep foundation allow it to fit comfortably within most frames.</p>\n<p>While under bed lightly doesn’t necessarily enhance sleep, it can help those who frequently get up to use the restroom during the night. With a click of the “light” button on the remote, soft lighting under the bed will illuminate a pathway around the bed frame and to the bedroom door.</p>\n<p>To help you relax before sleep, this foundation comes with full-body massage capabilities.
