Are sites whose theme or business typically revolve around travel suddenly linking to sites talking about CBD or insurance in a way that looks outlandishly like <a href=\"https://www.podbean.com/media/share/dir-xu4j2-97d8b84?utm_campaign=w_share_ep&#38;utm_medium=dlink&#38;utm_source=w_share\">link spam</a>?</p>\n<p><strong>Domain &#38; IP History</strong> – Has the domain been owned by the same person or entity since inception? If not, when the shift occurred was there a simultaneous shift in the theme, content and industry sector of the site itself? Was there a major shift in how frequently the site was posting? Has the way the outbound links looked varied heavily?</p>\n<p><strong>Redirects</strong> – Unless a company is doing a complete rebrand, links that were once ranking on one site should not regularly be funneled to another site to pass link equity. If redirects are occurring, it is more natural to have them occur sitewide.</p>\n<p><strong>TLD Extension</strong> – Certain TLD extensions are more frequently used for creating spam. Top Level Domain extensions like .info, .biz and even .co have been nefarious for this.</p>\n<p><strong>Site Legitimacy</strong> – Illegitimate websites typically exclude things like social accounts with legitimate followers in tow. In contrast, links from real websites</p>\n<p>In each of the areas listed above, robot algorithms are getting better at understanding the real from the fake. They also are getting better at looking for patterns in what constitutes a spam backlink. In cases where a telling number of violations occur from any of the above, bots may trigger a manual review which could jeopardize the amount of time you have spent building out your SEO.</p>\n<h2><strong>The Misnomer of Negative SEO</strong></h2>\n<p>Ten years ago, a strategy known as “Google Bowling” was effectively implemented by competitors looking to tank sites ranking higher than them in the SERPs. In doing so, competitors could hire cheap contractors from sites like Fiverr to quickly impact the link profile of specific pages on a website using spam sites and manipulated links using phrases that only spammers might use.</p>\n<p>Lucky for most legitimate businesses, the algorithms can almost bat a thousand when it comes to completely ignoring links from heinous attacks like this.</p>\n<p>While such attacks are obvious, knowing how they occur and how manipulating link building occurs are one in the same. If you find someone manipulating their profile, it will be that much easier to use them as their own case study and find the pattern that can help to identify others doing the same thing.</p>\n<p>Find the pattern and you can find the offenders.</p>\n<h2><strong>How the Future Looks for Spam Link Builders </strong></h2>\n<p>The human, <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/01/27/how-will-ai-change-the-future-of-seo/\">manual elements of SEO are quickly disappearing</a>. Yes, human’s currently control the bots that are making the decisions and humans are creating the content that is being consumed, but what happens when the algorithm gets smart enough when they know the links they are seeing look manipulative, unnatural or down right shady?</p>\n<p>More importantly, as search algorithms improve, they continue to place less emphasis on hyperlink-based signals in general, instead opting for user dwell time, bounce rates and direct user feedback. Consequently, even those who play by the rules when it comes to manual link building are also most likely to be demoted compared to competitors if the user experience is not at least at par.</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/02/10/artificial-intelligence-link-building-spam/\">How AI Will Help Eradicate Spam Backlinks</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 10 Feb 2020 22:55:53 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/artificial-intelligence-link-building-spam.jpg","linkMd5":"3dbadf75ee3f2823af7656594fb93210","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn15@2020_5/2020/08/23/15-18-26-687_1def59f95ed06b63.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/artificial-intelligence-link-building-spam.jpg","destWidth":1920,"destHeight":1280,"sourceBytes":122125,"destBytes":89582,"author":"Nate Nead","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/artificial-intelligence-link-building-spam-300x200.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn4@2020_3/2020/08/23/15-18-18-520_d4697b2540e3bdc1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195881216},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:57","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:57","title":"How Will Autonomous Cars Affect Insurance?","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=171084","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/05/12/how-will-autonomous-cars-affect-insurance/\" title=\"How Will Autonomous Cars Affect Insurance?\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"199\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Screen-Shot-2020-05-06-at-9.13.18-AM-300x199.png\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Screen-Shot-2020-05-06-at-9.13.18-AM-300x199.png 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Screen-Shot-2020-05-06-at-9.13.18-AM-241x160.png 241w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Screen-Shot-2020-05-06-at-9.13.18-AM.png 890w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></div><p>Autonomous cars aren&#8217;t a new concept. Almost all the major automakers are developing autonomous cars of some sort. Some, like Tesla’s Autopilot and Google’s Waymo, are already in use, though they&#8217;re not fully autonomous yet. Tesla and Waymo, like so many other automakers in the autonomous car race, are still ironing out the kinks.</p>\n<p>In the meantime, one of the biggest debates surrounding driverless cars is how they&#8217;ll impact the insurance industry. Human error accounts for 94% of road accidents, according to the <a href=\"https://crashstats.nhtsa.dot.gov/Api/Public/ViewPublication/812115\">National Highway Traffic Safety Administration</a>. If human error causes almost all car accidents, then in theory, self-driving cars are the solution. But if self-driving technology succeeds in preventing car accidents, how will this affect car insurance?</p>\n<h2>Will Auto Insurance Still Be Necessary?</h2>\n<p>If autonomous cars make driving safer, will we still need insurance? The short answer: yes. Insurance is still necessary, but it will need to adapt. Technology may eliminate human error in driving, but tech isn&#8217;t infallible. Tesla already has a <a href=\"https://www.vox.com/recode/2020/2/26/21154502/tesla-autopilot-fatal-crashes\">record of fatal car crashes</a> with its autopilot function.</p>\n<p>Self-driving cars operate by using a system of cameras, radar, laser sensors (called lidar), and other technology to assess road conditions and adjust driving behavior. <a href=\"https://waymo.com/tech/\">Waymo</a>, for instance, has cameras that can see up to three football fields in all directions. Waymo cars also have software that can predict the movement of everything in close proximity to the vehicle, including bicyclists and pedestrians. If any of those systems fail, it can result in a crash.</p>\n<p>Autonomous vehicles are undoubtedly going to be a game changer for the insurance industry. Here are three likely scenarios that will play out as the industry adapts to driverless cars:</p>\n<h2>1. Insurance Rates Will Drop</h2>\n<p>As we slowly progress toward fully autonomous cars, car accidents should decrease. With fewer accidents, insurance rates should drop.</p>\n<p>Fully autonomous won’t take to the roads overnight. The path to autonomous vehicles is gradually taking place across <a href=\"https://www.truecar.com/blog/5-levels-autonomous-vehicles/\">five levels of automation</a>. Most cars today feature levels 1 or 2 automation: cruise control, electronic stability control, forward-collision warning, automated emergency braking, and self-parking. The <a href=\"https://www.audi-mediacenter.com/en/on-autopilot-into-the-future-the-audi-vision-of-autonomous-driving-9305/the-new-audi-a8-conditional-automated-at-level-3-9307\">Audi 8</a> was the first production car to reach level-3 automation.</p>\n<p>If we&#8217;re indeed headed toward a world of level-5 autonomous vehicles, there will be a period in which both human-operated and self-driving cars share the roads. The risk to insurers will still be high. As self-driving cars become commonplace and lead to lower rates, insurance companies will have to change their business model to survive.</p>\n<h2>2. Auto Manufacturers Will Be Held Liable</h2>\n<p>With self-driving cars, one of the big questions is what happens to the liability portion of your insurance policy? <a href=\"https://www.thezebra.com/auto-insurance/insurance-guide/liability-insurance/\">Liability car insurance</a> covers injury to the other driver or damage to the vehicle, should you be at fault.</p>\n<p>With autonomous cars, the experts foresee that the liability in a crash would shift from the driver to the product. That means manufacturers and suppliers will be liable for accidents caused by a product defect in the car. Personal liability insurance may become obsolete altogether.</p>\n<p>Up until now, personal auto insurance has brought in a large chunk of insurance companies&#8217; revenue. The U.S. auto insurance industry <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/patricklin/2016/04/25/self-driving-cars-wont-kill-insurance-industry/#263b9f19746f\">generates around $220 billion</a> in annual revenue. It’s predicted that this could fall by a massive 60% by 2040. Autonomous vehicles are sure to play a role in declining revenue for the insurance industry as auto insurance premiums are slashed.</p>\n<p>This by no means signals the death of auto insurance. If a product, rather than a human, is responsible for an accident, it makes sense that the manufacturer should be held responsible. Shifting from consumer liability to manufacturer liability will keep the insurance industry afloat. The <a href=\"https://www.iii.org/article/background-on-self-driving-cars-and-insurance\">Insurance Information Institute</a> suggests that even local municipalities may be called upon to take responsibility when accidents involving self-driving cars occur in their jurisdictions.</p>\n<h2>3. No-Fault Liability May Become Standard</h2>\n<p>There’s no reason to think collisions will never happen in a world of self-driving cars. No-fault liability may become standard practice across all states in the U.S. for these types of claims. Faulty technology can cause crashes or cause your car to misjudge distances and hit another car or object. Insurance will still be required to repair damaged vehicles. And these repairs will be costly when high-tech components need replacing.</p>\n<p>Additionally, car crashes may decrease with autonomous vehicles, but other risk factors remain. Car break-ins and theft will still occur. Inclement weather and other road hazards will still present dangers. Insurance will still be needed for these risks.</p>\n<p>Self-driving cars are going to be a part of our future, and they&#8217;ll disrupt the current insurance model. Precisely how the insurance industry will change is still unclear. It is, however, a talking point on most insurance companies’ agendas. At this point, no one can say for sure how risky autonomous driving is. Until more solid evidence exists on safety, the shift is likely to be gradual as the insurance industry assesses the risk posed by self-driving vehicles.</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/05/12/how-will-autonomous-cars-affect-insurance/\">How Will Autonomous Cars Affect Insurance?</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 12 May 2020 14:00:00 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Screen-Shot-2020-05-06-at-9.13.18-AM.png","linkMd5":"00bbbc8dd8a53f1e6249949e94c16246","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn2@2020_5/2020/08/23/15-18-09-814_31b8e4ba567e9d35.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Screen-Shot-2020-05-06-at-9.13.18-AM.png","destWidth":890,"destHeight":590,"sourceBytes":761339,"destBytes":43866,"author":"Brad Anderson","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Screen-Shot-2020-05-06-at-9.13.18-AM-300x199.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn32@2020_5/2020/08/23/15-18-14-920_e241b095fdc0194d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195877747},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:52","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:52","title":"Best Ways to Use Credit Cards to Increase Your Credit Score","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=173268","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/07/31/best-ways-to-use-credit-cards-to-increase-your-credit-score/\" title=\"Best Ways to Use Credit Cards to Increase Your Credit Score\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"185\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Best-Ways-to-Use-Credit-Cards-to-Increase-Your-Credit-Score-300x185.jpg\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"increase your credit score\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Best-Ways-to-Use-Credit-Cards-to-Increase-Your-Credit-Score-300x185.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Best-Ways-to-Use-Credit-Cards-to-Increase-Your-Credit-Score-260x160.jpg 260w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Best-Ways-to-Use-Credit-Cards-to-Increase-Your-Credit-Score.jpg 825w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></div><p>A plethora of websites may suggest to you a hoopla of best ways to increase your credit score but how successful are these tips and tricks, ever wondered? Your <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/02/15/is-a-tech-based-social-credit-score-a-good-idea/\"><strong>credit score</strong> </a>reflects how well you use your credit and is thus, immensely important during the requirement of any kind of loan. It is, thereby, important to be aware of the factors that may affect your <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/04/12/10-ways-your-credit-score-will-impact-your-financial-future/\"><strong>credit score</strong></a> as well as the measures that may improve it. I have brought you the best and some do it yourself ways on how to improve your <b>credit score in UAE</b> using <strong><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/01/27/what-does-your-credit-card-company-know-about-you/\">your credit cards</a></strong>.</p>\n<h2><b>Ensure that you pay your credit card monthly bills on time</b></h2>\n<ul>\n<li>A history of late payments and other delinquent behavior can have a strong negative effect on your credit scores for many years.</li>\n<li>To avoid missing your due date, set a reminder on your phone a few days beforehand or mark the date on your calendar. You can also adjust your online account settings to always automatically pay at least the minimum required amount each month.</li>\n<li>Or, better yet, <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/05/20/how-ai-technologies-help-banks-and-fintech-startups/\">set up automatic payments</a> to pay the full new statement balance each month. To avoid heavy interest rates, you must pay the bill in full.</li>\n<li>This can help you both stay out of credit card debt and avoid interest completely with most cards.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2><b>Keep your credit card utilization low</b></h2>\n<ul>\n<li>Credit scoring models look at how much of your available credit you’re using on each credit card in UAE, and how much of your total credit limit is being used across all cards.</li>\n<li>They do this by calculating the <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/01/03/increasing-business-credit-the-safe-and-smart-way/\">percentage of your credit limit</a> you’re using, as reflected on your credit reports. This percentage is called ‘credit utilization.’</li>\n<li>Using a high percentage of your credit limit is seen as very risky. It may indicate that you’re overextended financially and may have trouble paying your bills as a result.</li>\n<li>Generally, the lower your credit utilization, both overall and on each individual account, the better it is for your score.</li>\n<li>So, opening a new card or increasing the credit limits of cards you already have could potentially have a large positive impact on your credit scores.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2><b>Avoid applying for many credit cards in a short period of time</b></h2>\n<ul>\n<li>Opening many new accounts in a short period of time can be seen as risky financial behavior because it looks like you’re in need of money and are acting recklessly.</li>\n<li>This ‘new credit’ factor considered in your credit scores is where the number of inquiries and length of time since your most recent inquiry comes into play. The length of time since you last opened an account can also be factored in here.</li>\n<li>While every new inquiry and every new account won’t automatically have a negative impact on your scores, there’s always a possibility that it could. Many hard inquiries can have a negative effect on your credit scores.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2><b>Increase the length of your credit card history</b></h2>\n<ul>\n<li>The older your credit history, the better. If you established accounts a long time ago and have been able to manage them responsibly, that demonstrates to lenders that you’re less risky than someone who doesn’t have a very long credit history.</li>\n<li>If you take the length of time each of your accounts has been open and average them together, that’s the average length of your credit history. This average is considered in credit scores because you’re seen as less risky to lenders the longer your accounts have been open. The ages of your newest and oldest accounts are also considered.</li>\n<li>When you open a new credit card and already have some older credit cards, you’ll reduce the average age of your accounts. This could potentially have a negative effect on your scores.</li>\n<li>There are two potential ways to improve your credit scores within this category. First, you can wait for the accounts on your reports to age. You should be careful about adding new credit accounts because every time you do you’ll reduce the average age of your accounts.</li>\n<li>Second, you can ask a loved one to add you to an existing, older credit card account as an authorized user. If you’re added onto an older account with positive payment history, it might increase your average age of accounts.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Using the <b>best credit card in UAE</b> (moneymall) has a <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2012/04/25/examining_the_future_of_mobile_money_part_2/\">direct influence on the most important factors </a>that go into establishing your credit score. So getting a credit card and using it regularly and responsibly is one of the quickest and most effective ways to build or rebuild your credit score. We hope that you will follow these guidelines for the effective use of your credit card.</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/07/31/best-ways-to-use-credit-cards-to-increase-your-credit-score/\">Best Ways to Use Credit Cards to Increase Your Credit Score</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 31 Jul 2020 15:01:04 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Best-Ways-to-Use-Credit-Cards-to-Increase-Your-Credit-Score.jpg","linkMd5":"b41c99a7004f031a0bae554e58c06263","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn87@2020_1/2020/08/23/15-18-27-010_c38e56ab1733d369.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Best-Ways-to-Use-Credit-Cards-to-Increase-Your-Credit-Score.jpg","destWidth":825,"destHeight":510,"sourceBytes":36549,"destBytes":29358,"author":"Aashirvad Kumar","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Best-Ways-to-Use-Credit-Cards-to-Increase-Your-Credit-Score-300x185.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn64@2020_4/2020/08/23/15-18-19-253_79a18ca287abd75a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195872336},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:56","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:56","title":"The Three Keys to Working from Home","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=172058","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/06/04/the-three-keys-to-working-from-home/\" title=\"The Three Keys to Working from Home\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"200\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-Three-Keys-to-Working-from-Home-300x200.jpg\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"keys working from home\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-Three-Keys-to-Working-from-Home-300x200.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-Three-Keys-to-Working-from-Home-900x600.jpg 900w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-Three-Keys-to-Working-from-Home-240x160.jpg 240w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-Three-Keys-to-Working-from-Home-1536x1024.jpg 1536w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-Three-Keys-to-Working-from-Home.jpg 1920w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></div><p>Companies across the globe are unexpectedly embracing <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/04/16/thanks-covid-remote-work-is-now-mandatory/\">working from home </a>out of necessity. In fact, according to a recent<a href=\"https://news.gallup.com/poll/306695/workers-discovering-affinity-remote-work.aspx\"> Gallup Poll, </a>62% of employed Americans currently say they have worked from home during the crisis.</p>\n<p>At Open Raven, we were founded and remain a <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/02/07/remote-first-why-isnt-every-company-boundaryless/\">100% remote team</a>. There’s no shortage of great resources and tips available for working remotely, but in my experience, there are three big topics that determine team and personal success when working from home:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Getting communication right.</li>\n<li>Understanding and neutralizing negativity bias.</li>\n<li>Structuring your day.</li>\n</ol>\n<p>Yes, other stuff matters. However, if you do these three things well, you and your business have a good chance of being successful even if you don’t nail everything else.</p>\n<h2><b>1. Getting Communications Right</b></h2>\n<p>If you were to rate the percentage of <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/04/08/big-data-in-the-telecommunications-ecosystem/\">communication</a> that was the actual “content” (e.g., the words, slides, etc.), what would it be? Well, according to a famous study by <a href=\"https://www.psych.ucla.edu/faculty/page/mehrab\"> Dr. Mehrabian</a>, less than 10% of communication is verbal.</p>\n<p>Think about it: If you’re talking on the phone, you can get your words across, at least, with your voice tone. What about facial expressions, gestures, or posture? Only having the verbal aspect of a conversation and no non-verbal signals means that you’re losing at least half of the intended meaning.</p>\n<p>Add <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/11/13/7-critical-time-management-skills-to-boost-your-productivity/\">multi-tasking</a> into the mix where people are distracted and not listening to verbal communication; it results in poor communication. Not to mention the absence of a personal connection between both parties.</p>\n<h3>To help communication in a remote work setting, we need to recognize that there are different types of meetings – “formal” meetings and “informal” meetings – and each meets different needs.</h3>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>Formal Meetings – </b>are a small group of people focused on a predetermined topic. There is no magical solution to replace traditional formal meetings when everyone is remote, but <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/03/26/the-modern-workplace-demands-better-visibility/\">modern video conferencing</a> restores much of the fidelity lost when in-person contact isn’t possible. Notably, it brings back facial expressions, gestures, and posture.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>Informal Meetings – </b>These are unscheduled conversations. Video conferencing can simulate an in-person meeting, but it does a poor job of replacing the impromptu conversations that are the mainstay of “ informal meetings. ” Since these are low-risk conversations, I find a simple phone call is fine.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>To make these better, I find it helpful to have a loose agenda that touches on how things are going, what the person you’re talking to is working on currently if they feel like they need anything they’re not getting at the moment, and so on. It’s also helpful to keep these to 15-20 minutes and try to do these calls walking outside or at least away from the distraction of your laptop screen.</p>\n<p>Further, <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/03/30/3-ways-you-can-empower-your-remote-employees/\">virtual team lunches</a>, happy hours, or other unstructured time with each other can help offset the time you would have typically had in-person to help forge and maintain bonds with one another.</p>\n<h2><b>2. Understanding and Neutralizing Negativity Bias</b></h2>\n<p>As humans, we all have the subconscious tendency to exaggerate the negative and downplay the positive. If you are unfamiliar with it, this phenomenon is well documented as “<a href=\"https://www.verywellmind.com/negative-bias-4589618\">the negativity bias</a>.”</p>\n<p>When you’re not face-to-face in an office, and <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/12/05/remote-working-culture-the-facts-business-owners-need-to-know/\">you&#8217;re working from home</a>, you’re relegated to lower fidelity conversations (e.g., Slack versus a watercooler conversation). Out of visual contact leaves you interpreting communications much more than you have to do in person. With negativity bias, instead of giving the other person the benefit of the doubt, your natural instinct is to assume the worst. Simply stated, the extra “white space” you have when working remote is far too easy to fill with negativity.</p>\n<h3>To offset negativity bias in a remote setting, I recommend you do the following:</h3>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>Be clear about tone –</b> State your intent. Assume it won’t be clear otherwise. Leave less whitespace by exaggerating the positive and use emojis or whatever suits you to clarify statements.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>Celebrate and savor the good moments –</b> Let them burn into your brain. Give yourself, others, and the whole team credit. Build a reservoir of positive thoughts to draw from.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>Give the benefit of the doubt –</b> Our own internal narrative is more often the culprit of perceived negativity rather than the intent of the other person. So try to refrain from premature judgment.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>Breathe – </b>Count to 10 deep breaths, use the Apple Breathe feature for a couple of minutes, or <a href=\"https://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-lifestyle/stress-management/in-depth/decrease-stress-by-using-your-breath/art-20267197\">whatever works for you</a>. It will reduce the impact of stress-based reactions and diminish the exaggerated responses that come so easy today, given the mountain of extra stress we are all feeling.</li>\n</ul>\n<h2>3. <b>Structuring Your Day</b></h2>\n<p><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/04/15/new-data-shows-covid-shifts-newly-remote-work-behavior/\">Before</a>, when you would leave your home to go into an office, you had a clear cognitive signal of when the workday began and the same signal when you would leave work. Now, when you’re working from home instead of in a separate, <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/07/03/how-tech-startups-succeed-with-a-fully-remote-model/\">designated workspace</a> like a company office, both the start and end signals are gone.</p>\n<p>Your regular morning routine and the drive for getting ready evaporates since you’re “just staying at home.” If you do nothing to create a structure for your day, the most natural outcome is haphazard attention to how you look and feel. When the start of your workday is signaled by when you first check your phone in the early morning and then drag on well through the evening with no clear end, it can cause fatigue or even burnout.</p>\n<p>On top of losing traditional start/stop signals that were previously tied to your external workplace, people can no longer meet ad hoc. As a result, everything turns into a scheduled meeting. Your calendar is now packed tight.</p>\n<h3>To help take back control of your daily schedule, I propose the following:</h3>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>No meetings longer than 45 minutes</b> – The <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/10/03/connected-digital-assistants-will-change-the-way-we-work/\">15 minutes between meetings</a> will allow you to attend to biological realities and enable you to mentally shift gears between meetings. It also means that if one meeting runs a little over, you’re not always running late, trying to catch up for the remainder of the day.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>Force empty space into your schedule</b> – The way I personally use this technique is by working in the early morning (my “priming time”) and then stopping to exercise, often by myself, with music playing on my headphones (no lyrics). I find this gives me optimal chances at solving thorny problems when I return to my work later in the morning.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>Treat mental energy as a fixed resource</b> – The idea here is that you only have so much cognitive power each day, and once you use it, it’s gone. At some point, you’ve burned through all your high potency brainpower, and you’re then stuck with gut-level decision making where your biases are primarily in control of your thinking. So how can you make sure to use your best energy for your most significant opportunities or to tackle the most prominent problems? <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/05/27/8-reasons-to-implement-an-mft-strategy/\">Schedule it</a> early in the day and protect the time. Save the easy stuff (email, calendaring, expenses, etc.) for later when you know you’ll be working with less mental savvy.</li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><b>Start using a shutdown sequence</b> – <a href=\"https://www.calnewport.com/blog/2009/06/08/drastically-reduce-stress-with-a-work-shutdown-ritual/\">Cal Newport </a>has a method he uses for turning off work for the day that can help reestablish your evening boundary. Take a systematic review of work that was done, tasks for tomorrow, and a glance at the upcoming weeks. Once complete, close down your computer and say the magic phrase: “schedule shutdown, complete.”</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>Cal Newport</strong> asks the question: &#8220;What do you do when work comes knocking again after shutdown?&#8221;</p>\n<h3>Here is the Newport rule: &#8220;After I’ve uttered the magic phrase if a work-related worry pops to mind, I always answer it with the following thought process:</h3>\n<ol>\n<li>I said the termination phrase.</li>\n<li>I wouldn’t have said this phrase if I hadn’t checked over all of my tasks, my calendar, and my weekly plan and decided that everything was captured, and I was on top of everything.</li>\n<li>Therefore, there is no need to worry.&#8221;</li>\n</ol>\n<h4><b>Wrap-up</b></h4>\n<p>Working from home may not be for everyone, and this situation should be temporary for most of us, but in the meantime, it is our reality. Use these tips to help create the right approach for you – one that allows you the right balance while you work from home.</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/06/04/the-three-keys-to-working-from-home/\">The Three Keys to Working from Home</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 04 Jun 2020 15:00:50 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-Three-Keys-to-Working-from-Home.jpg","linkMd5":"752793fd21158478c51c380671b1c4fa","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn95@2020_3/2020/08/23/15-18-25-676_92f537c460e4bb65.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-Three-Keys-to-Working-from-Home.jpg","destWidth":1920,"destHeight":1280,"sourceBytes":300633,"destBytes":143772,"author":"Dave Cole","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/The-Three-Keys-to-Working-from-Home-300x200.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn51@2020_2/2020/08/23/15-18-12-034_60249a8d17e1008c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195876938},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:18:00","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:18:00","title":"Impact of Voice Search on SEO rankings in 2020: 5 Tips to Optimize","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=165871","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/03/07/impact-of-voice-search-on-seo-rankings-in-2020-5-tips-to-optimize/\" title=\"Impact of Voice Search on SEO rankings in 2020: 5 Tips to Optimize\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"185\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Impact-of-Voice-Search-on-SEO-rankings-in-2020-300x185.png\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"impact of voice search\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Impact-of-Voice-Search-on-SEO-rankings-in-2020-300x185.png 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Impact-of-Voice-Search-on-SEO-rankings-in-2020-260x160.png 260w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Impact-of-Voice-Search-on-SEO-rankings-in-2020.png 825w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></div><p>Think back &#8212; or imagine.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s the mid-1900s. You’re on a work trip to a new location. You’re starving.</p>\n<p>How do you find a place to eat?</p>\n<p>Your options include a physical map, and maybe if you’re lucky, you run into a stranger who can give you a recommendation.</p>\n<p>Now let’s fast forward a few decades and alas &#8212; the world gifts you the internet. But the world doesn&#8217;t stop there.</p>\n<p>Soon after, the world gives you the internet through a portable device &#8212; your mobile phone. How equipped are you now to find a place to eat?</p>\n<p>And if things couldn’t get any better. Now the world’s given you voice search.</p>\n<h2>What is a voice search?</h2>\n<p><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/11/21/is-voice-search-the-next-big-travel-technology-trend/\">Voice search</a> is a convenient alternative to traditional text-based searches.</p>\n<p>Now, twiddling your thumbs for an answer is more convenient than figuring your way around a physical map. But let’s face it &#8212; We’re now in the 20th century and searching for answers through <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/12/09/a-web-developers-new-best-friend-is-the-ai-waiting-to-be-utilized/\">text-based queries</a> isn’t the most convenient thing.</p>\n<p>We needed a more natural search &#8212; because we are searching while we’re trying to exercise or do the dishes. What’s a step above text-based queries on the convenience scale? Well, something hands-free. And that&#8217;s where voice search comes in.</p>\n<p>Voice search became a thing, and now there are about one billion <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/02/28/the-potential-impact-of-voice-enabled-tech-in-2020/\">voice searches</a> done per month. We know voice search is growing at a super-fast rate because of the convenience factor. But how does this affect SEO rankings in 2020?</p>\n<h2>5 Ways to Optimize SEO Rankings with Voice Search</h2>\n<ol>\n<li>\n<h4><strong>Optimize for questions.</strong></h4>\n</li>\n</ol>\n<p>Compared to <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/12/09/a-web-developers-new-best-friend-is-the-ai-waiting-to-be-utilized/\">text-based queries</a>, voice queries are more likely to be in a question format. This not only means that you need the best answers, but it means you need to know the right questions. What are the right questions? The questions your audience is asking, of course.</p>\n<p>When looking for coffee, consider the query from a typical text searcher :</p>\n<p>“bar miami.”</p>\n<p>Now consider the query from a voice searcher:</p>\n<p>“What’s the best bar in Miami?”</p>\n<p>Make sure to <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/02/24/top-tips-to-increase-website-conversions/\">optimize your website</a> and content to answer the more specific questions.</p>\n<p>If you need some help learning what your audience is asking, there is plenty of resources out there. One way to learn is by using tools like FAQFox, which allows you to see <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/01/27/9-ways-to-refresh-your-companys-image-without-spending-a-fortune/\">what your target audience</a> is asking just by answering a few questions yourself.</p>\n<h4><strong>2. Optimize local SEO.</strong></h4>\n<p>Compared to a text-based search, voice search on mobile is 3x more likely to be local-based. On top of that, between 2018-2019, 58% of consumers found local businesses using voice search.</p>\n<p>You don’t need a degree in statistics to understand that it’s so crucial to optimizing local SEO in 2020. You can do this by learning it on your own or by looking for a local <a href=\"https://www.ambientetechnologies.com/effective-seo-services/\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">online SEO services agency</a> in your area. If you’re looking to do it on your own, a few quick things you can do is to make sure your business address is displaying correctly on search engines and to learn about structured data and schema mark-up.</p>\n<h4><strong>3. Answer questions directly and conversationally.</strong></h4>\n<p>A shift to a more natural language has become evident with voice search. With voice search, people conversationally ask questions, as if talking to a friend. Conversational voice means the <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/07/01/ultimate-guide-for-voice-search-optimization-in-2019/\">user wants and expects answers back</a> in the same way.</p>\n<p>Can you imagine you meet a lady who owns a yoga studio, and you ask her, “Hey, what are the health benefits of yoga?” and she replies, “Yoga has lots of health benefits. So many successful people do it. Here’s my business card. It has a link to my website where you can watch a 15-minute video on why you should do yoga.”</p>\n<p>Kind of annoying, right? You still don&#8217;t have an answer to your question.</p>\n<p>You have a million and one things competing for your attention, so you most likely will either stop caring about the answer to that question or look elsewhere for a quick response.</p>\n<p>In an analysis of 850,000 queries, it shows that Google served a direct answer <a href=\"https://www.cio.com/article/2919092/how-voice-search-and-google-direct-answers-are-changing-seo.html\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">19.5% of the time</a>, so there’s an apparent preference by Google for immediate responses. Don&#8217;t beat around the bush with the <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/07/12/communication-re-imagined-with-emotion-ai/\">answers to the questions</a> your audience is asking.</p>\n<p>Don’t be a Yoga girl.</p>\n<h4><strong>4. Use long-tail keywords.</strong></h4>\n<p>It’s no secret that it’s harder and longer to type than it is to talk. So naturally, voice searches tend to be longer than text-based searches.</p>\n<p>Think about the past. If you were <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/02/25/how-voice-assistant-marketing-can-future-proof-your-brand/\">searching for coffee</a>, you’d put in a query similar to “coffee best.” Now since talking is easier, you’re more likely to put in a longer question such as “where’s the best coffee in Miami?”</p>\n<p>Use this to your advantage and make sure to include these longer tailed keywords in your site. This can be something simple like “We’ve been told that we’re the best coffee in Miami.”</p>\n<p>And don&#8217;t forget, people expect answers quickly, so if you provide solutions by making them have to jump through hoops to find what they’re looking for, they won’t like you. And <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/01/16/heres-what-you-need-to-know-about-search-in-2020/\">if your audience doesn’t like you,</a> Google will not like you. If Google doesn’t like you, you won’t rank favorably in the search pages.</p>\n<h4><strong>5. Make your site secure.</strong></h4>\n<p>There are so many benefits for making your site secure (HTTP vs. HTTPS), but I’ll list only two of them as it appeals to SEO:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Over 65% of the results from voice search are websites that are HTTPS.</li>\n<li>HTTPS makes your site faster, which is a super important factor in SEO.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Need I say more?</p>\n<p>I believe not.</p>\n<h4><strong>Final Thoughts</strong></h4>\n<p>It’s no secret that we love convenience. Trends prove this. Just think about Uber, Amazon, and Airbnb. What do they all have in common?</p>\n<p>They’ve <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2018/04/12/3-major-ways-tech-is-making-your-life-more-convenient/\">made things more convenient</a> for you and everyone with voice-search. Now, think of voice search as the Uber of the search industry. Voice search will revolutionize SEO in 2020 and moving forward.</p>\n<p>Now you know five ways to capitalize on the voice search movement. Don&#8217;t try to do all five right away; just pick one and get started today.</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/03/07/impact-of-voice-search-on-seo-rankings-in-2020-5-tips-to-optimize/\">Impact of Voice Search on SEO rankings in 2020: 5 Tips to Optimize</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 07 Mar 2020 16:00:48 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Impact-of-Voice-Search-on-SEO-rankings-in-2020.png","linkMd5":"3757a46156f275e2211969dfd3236e9f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn40@2020_3/2020/08/23/15-18-25-886_b847c6bca768df7d.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Impact-of-Voice-Search-on-SEO-rankings-in-2020.png","destWidth":825,"destHeight":510,"sourceBytes":287773,"destBytes":16052,"author":"Harmanjit Kaur","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Impact-of-Voice-Search-on-SEO-rankings-in-2020-300x185.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn19@2020_4/2020/08/23/15-18-12-231_017b6e99319cf198.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195880419},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:53","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:53","title":"Is AI Contributing to Climate Change and Delaying People Coming out of Poverty?","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=172057","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/07/12/is-ai-contributing-to-climate-change-and-delaying-people-coming-out-of-poverty/\" title=\"Is AI Contributing to Climate Change and Delaying People Coming out of Poverty?\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"200\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Is-AI-Delaying-People-Coming-out-of-Poverty-300x200.jpg\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"AI delaying people in poverty\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Is-AI-Delaying-People-Coming-out-of-Poverty-300x200.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Is-AI-Delaying-People-Coming-out-of-Poverty-900x600.jpg 900w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Is-AI-Delaying-People-Coming-out-of-Poverty-240x160.jpg 240w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Is-AI-Delaying-People-Coming-out-of-Poverty.jpg 1280w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></div><p>AI has become the buzzword of the world, and an integral part of almost every company’s digital transformation agenda. AI users have become producers of AI tools and services. Corporate leaders and even the White House have come with forward with a directive on promotion, promulgation, and advancement of artificial intelligence.</p>\n<p>On February 11, 2019, President Trump signed Executive Order 13859 announcing the American AI Initiative. Executive Order 13859 is the United States’ national strategy on artificial intelligence. 4000+ companies in the world are in the business of producing AI tools, products and services.</p>\n<p><img class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-172163\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/global-electricity-access-map.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"742\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/global-electricity-access-map.jpg 1200w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/global-electricity-access-map-300x186.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/global-electricity-access-map-900x557.jpg 900w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/global-electricity-access-map-260x160.jpg 260w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/global-electricity-access-map-825x510.jpg 825w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></p>\n<p><em><strong>AI and its impact on climate change.</strong> </em></p>\n<p>&#160;</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.gartner.com/en/newsroom/press-releases/2019-08-05-gartner-says-ai-augmentation-will-create-2point9-trillion-of-business-value-in-2021\">Gartner projects</a> that by 2021, AI will create $2.9 trillion in business value and generate 6.2 billion hours in worker productivity. In light of these assumptions, it&#8217;s no wonder that <a href=\"https://www.pwc.com/gx/en/issues/data-and-analytics/publications/artificial-intelligence-study.html\">PwC forecasts</a> that A.I. could contribute $15.7 trillion to the global economy by 2030.</p>\n<p>While the whole world is optimistic about AI-led use cases and championing huge investments, one thing is probably getting far less attention than it ideally should: AI – induced climate change.</p>\n<h3>Artificial intelligence advancement needs two key ingredients (other than passion):</h3>\n<ol>\n<li><strong>Tons of training data.</strong>\n<p>Machine learning models are nothing if there is no historical data to train them. Example, to train computer vision models to detect, identify and label objects that they see if a photo or a video, they need to be trained on corresponding, labeled and annotated data first for elongated periods of time, till they begin to use the learnings to then identify objects they might have seen before.</li>\n<li><strong>Correspondingly a lot of storage and computing power.\n<p></strong> Now, multiply this with millions of use cases companies are developing using computer vision to detect, identify, label, and then predict some, to get an idea of the amount of infrastructure being used.</li>\n</ol>\n<p>At a very conservative level, there were more than <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/941054/number-of-ai-companies-worldwide-by-country/\">4000* companies around the world in 2018</a>, and growing, dedicated to developing one or more specific uses cases using AI to automate human work in one form or another<strong>.</strong></p>\n<h4>What these 2 ingredients mean is that humungous amounts of energy requirements to store, backup and feature engineer this training data.</h4>\n<p>To give you an idea, few brainy folks @ University of Massachusetts Amherst measured that an average car produces 126,000 pounds of Co2 over its lifetime. Training a single transformer model to achieve acceptable levels of accuracy with 1 GPU over a neural architecture requires energy that would produce 626,000 pounds of Co2.</p>\n<p>That amount of Co2 is approximately equal to about 5 cars running their engines altogether for 10 years. That stat is teaching us that merely to train a single transformer model for AI is 5 cars running for 10 years.</p>\n<p>Extrapolating this to model building and training showing that those 4000+ AI companies are doing 24/7, it’s mind-boggling to see equivalent Co2 production and also the energy diversion towards ML training.</p>\n<h2>3 obvious questions arise.</h2>\n<ol>\n<li>How ethical is this AI process &#8212; especially when more than 940 Mn people in the <a href=\"https://ourworldindata.org/energy-access\">world do not have access to electricity</a>?</li>\n<li>When corporations say they support ‘green’ initiatives, how credible is that statement, when the same corps invest billions into AI? How is it possible to be still green when you invest in AI research? Google seems to be interesting– it uses 56% of its total power needs via renewable sources of energy. In comparison, Microsoft is at about 32% and Amazon at 17%. (Cook et al., 2017.)</li>\n<li>Is AI progression worth it, given the climate change impact due to such levels of Co2 production &#38; energy diversion away from the lower sections of society?</li>\n</ol>\n<h4>The counterargument that AI progression is creating more jobs.</h4>\n<p>So we have the counterargument that AI progression is creating more jobs and helping countries achieve a higher GDP and per capita rate. Is this a valid claim? Yes, but what remains to be examined closely is whether this is indeed new job creation or re-skilling existing manpower.</p>\n<p>The argument with every wave of technology, from the automatic weaving looms of the early industrial revolution to the computers of today, is that jobs are not destroyed, but rather an employment shifts from one place to another as entirely new categories of employment are created.</p>\n<p>The Luddites might have wrecked the mills as a protest against machine-enabled automation, but today, those same workers would be defending manufacturing against the disappearance of those jobs.</p>\n<h4>So are these additional jobs helping lift individuals out of poverty?</h4>\n<p>More importantly, are the additional jobs &#8212; if any. Are these supposed extra jobs actually lifting people out of poverty? Can someone work and finally have the money to finally get access to electricity? My thought is &#8212; is this the same electricity they could have had in the first place &#8212; had it not been diverted for purposes of advancing AI? Think about it.</p>\n<h3>Climate Change</h3>\n<p>Perhaps, the most fundamental of all is &#8212; What is it with AI that we can achieve that’s MORE important and precious than preserving our climate?</p>\n<p>Is investing in AI a really good bet for a socially responsible leadership? I don’t have an answer to this, but am often intrigued by this question.</p>\n<p><strong> I interestingly belong to that category of the society which has been propagating the cause of AI, and I am at my wit’s end to find balance against this question. Please weight in with your thoughts on this subject. I&#8217;d love to hear from you. </strong></p>\n<blockquote>\n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><em>These are personal views, and do not represent those of my current or previous employers.</em></p>\n</blockquote>\n<p><em>Top Image Credit: Denniz Futalan; Pexels</em></p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" Poverty?</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 12 Jul 2020 18:00:01 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Is-AI-Delaying-People-Coming-out-of-Poverty.jpg","linkMd5":"5456c2ef73a01ffa82f0303ec823fe03","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn20@2020_1/2020/08/23/15-18-27-359_5d605138de4238df.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Is-AI-Delaying-People-Coming-out-of-Poverty.jpg","destWidth":1280,"destHeight":853,"sourceBytes":200057,"destBytes":110802,"author":"Amit Arora","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Is-AI-Delaying-People-Coming-out-of-Poverty-300x200.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn87@2020_1/2020/08/23/15-18-16-818_d1a5486c6ea73873.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/global-electricity-access-map.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn59@2020_6/2020/08/23/15-18-27-877_d1ad4e19bb67a96d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195873642},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:18:00","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:18:00","title":"5 Ways Mobile Devices are the Biggest Threat to Cybersecurity","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=165752","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/03/12/5-ways-mobile-devices-are-the-biggest-threat-to-cybersecurity/\" title=\"5 Ways Mobile Devices are the Biggest Threat to Cybersecurity\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"185\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-Ways-Mobile-Devices-are-the-Biggest-Threat-to-Cybersecurity-300x185.jpg\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"mobile threat cybersecurity\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-Ways-Mobile-Devices-are-the-Biggest-Threat-to-Cybersecurity-300x185.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-Ways-Mobile-Devices-are-the-Biggest-Threat-to-Cybersecurity-260x160.jpg 260w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-Ways-Mobile-Devices-are-the-Biggest-Threat-to-Cybersecurity.jpg 825w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></div><p>Over time, mobile devices have experienced rapid development. The increase in the market purchase has made the mobile device man&#8217;s best friend &#8212; ahead of the trusty dog. Well, nearly. But there&#8217;s no doubt that the mobile device is now a man&#8217;s constant companion.</p>\n<p>The mobile functionality, multipurpose facilities, its handy nature, and its ability to do various tasks on and off the internet make it almost impossible to live without.</p>\n<p>Internet-connected mobile smartphones have presented many benefits to the <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/10/27/the-significant-role-of-smartphones-in-human-lives/\">work environment</a>. Also, mobile devices have helped in building social networks and relationships between people.</p>\n<p>However, in recent times, mobile devices are vulnerable and have become a breeding ground for hackers and spammers giving them access to some company data and personal databases. Furthermore, mobile devices are not often updated like personal computers (PC); hence; cyber attackers use the gap in a company’s security space to their own advantage.</p>\n<p>In the following paragraphs, five ways mobile devices are the biggest threat to cybersecurity will be discussed.</p>\n<ol>\n<li><b> Malware Attacks on Smartphone Operating System</b></li>\n</ol>\n<p>Malware is a software created by hackers to <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2015/02/04/sophisticated-hackers-defense-in-depth/\">disrupt computer operation,</a> steal sensitive information, and access private computer systems. Examples of malware include computer viruses, worms, spyware, and all other malicious programs.</p>\n<p>In a bid to decrease Malware attacks on smartphones, IT security specialists have studied malware attacks and have created various security products to combat such attacks. However, malware attacks on smartphones are fast evolving; an example of this is seen with <a href=\"https://www.enigmasoftware.com/zitmo-zeus-in-the-mobile-trojan-attacks-android-blackberry-smartphones/\">ZitMo</a> “Zeus-in-the-Mobile.”</p>\n<p>ZitMo malware is targeted mainly on Android operator’s bank apps; it attempts to bypass the two-factor authentication of the bank application, steal credentials and gain access to bank accounts, which could ultimately be disastrous for the victims.</p>\n<ol start=\"2\">\n<li><b> Social Networking and Electronic Commerce (E-Commerce) Applications</b></li>\n</ol>\n<p>Smartphones do numerous activities, like sending emails, storing contact information, <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/12/06/small-business-cybersecurity-threats-and-how-to-fix-the-fox/\">passwords, and other vital data</a>. In addition to this, smartphones are devices of choice when it comes to social networking; thus, mobile applications for social networking sites (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc.) are another breeding ground for <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/12/27/3-amazing-strategies-that-will-burst-cybercrimes-in-2020/\">cyber attackers</a> to gain personal data from smartphone users.</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2018/10/12/todays-social-platforms-are-dangerous-can-mappen-build-a-safer-one/\">Social networking sites</a> are host to a surplus of personal data. That is why <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2012/02/15/juniper_mobile_malware_increased_155_in_2011/\">malicious applications </a>use social networking sites to steal data and yield severe consequences.</p>\n<ol start=\"3\">\n<li><b> Smartphones Permissions</b></li>\n</ol>\n<p>Smartphones use permission mechanisms to determine what users are allowed to do in applications. The permissions are achieved through the &#8220;manifest permission&#8221; that grant these permissions to the applications independently. In turn, this process will allow an application to run independently from each other as well as from the operating system.</p>\n<p>However, the capability of allowing applications to seek permission outside of their sandbox capabilities could be harmful to smartphones because it creates an opportunity for <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/06/12/is-your-vpn-masking-your-online-privacy-or-exploiting-your-data-6-ways-to-find-out/\">malware to exploit</a> the ability to access sensitive data on Android handsets and thus install malicious software.</p>\n<ol start=\"4\">\n<li><b> Smart Mobile Web Browsers</b></li>\n</ol>\n<p>Web browsers are the most commonly used <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/10/27/the-significant-role-of-smartphones-in-human-lives/\">applications on smartphones</a>; they are used to <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/02/08/detecting-and-protecting-against-ransomware-best-practice-for-2020/\">gain access to the internet</a>. Every browser is advanced with updated usability and ubiquity, hence, each browser consists of some perceived and real benefits.</p>\n<p>The bad combinations</p>\n<p>However, web browsers are more prone to vulnerabilities and <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/03/22/6-emerging-cyber-threats-to-lookout-for-in-2019/\">cyberthreats</a> when users access websites that hold possible risks of malware and other threats in it, for example &#8212; bookmarks paired with saved logins &#8212; for an associated site &#8212; these are a very bad combination.</p>\n<p>The combinations have a high risk to your system and personal data because cybercriminals can gain access to your personal data and system when you visit sites with possible threats in it and can operate on your account from wherever.</p>\n<ol start=\"5\">\n<li><b> Wi-fi Interference</b></li>\n</ol>\n<p>The <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/07/31/healthcare-cybersecurity-tips-to-help-protect-your-data/\">security protocol</a> used to protect the vast majority of wifi connections has been broken, likely exposing wireless internet traffic to malicious sleuth and attacks, according to the researchers who discovered the weakness.</p>\n<p>An unsecured public wireless network combined with unsecured file-sharing could allow a malicious user to access any directories and files you have unintentionally made available for sharing.</p>\n<p>Not all attackers rely on <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/08/29/is-cloud-hosted-data-really-more-secure/\">gaining access to your data</a> via physically stealing your device. Attackers could have unrestricted access to all of your data, as well as any connected cloud accounts once they <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/02/21/connected-devices-in-the-workplace-what-you-need-to-know/\">gain access to a free and public wireless</a> network.</p>\n<p><b>Conclusion</b></p>\n<p>Soon, the society can expect to experience a striking increase in malware and notable <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/01/23/how-iot-has-exposed-business-organizations-to-cyber-attacks/\">advancements in malware-related attacks</a>, not particularly directed to smartphone users as the user base has grown exponentially.</p>\n<p>Fortunately, there are possible solutions to the rampant<a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/01/15/4-ethical-concerns-for-the-connected-world/\"> cybersecurity problem with smartphones</a>. Once the society acknowledges that cybersecurity threats are detrimental not only to one smartphone user but to society as a whole, then the inception of a solution can begin.</p>\n<p>The <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/01/10/big-data-and-its-impact-on-business-and-mobile-apps/\">value of data</a> is steadily increasing, possibly even more so than actual money. It is imperative to establish a culture of cybersecurity because this issue is multifaceted, and technology is continuously evolving.</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/03/12/5-ways-mobile-devices-are-the-biggest-threat-to-cybersecurity/\">5 Ways Mobile Devices are the Biggest Threat to Cybersecurity</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 12 Mar 2020 15:00:43 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-Ways-Mobile-Devices-are-the-Biggest-Threat-to-Cybersecurity.jpg","linkMd5":"b6a90dcb79df64c355ccd9b994ef375b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn91@2020_2/2020/08/23/15-18-22-382_e2652db59c1d40ff.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-Ways-Mobile-Devices-are-the-Biggest-Threat-to-Cybersecurity.jpg","destWidth":825,"destHeight":510,"sourceBytes":51741,"destBytes":50042,"author":"Joseph Okoye","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-Ways-Mobile-Devices-are-the-Biggest-Threat-to-Cybersecurity-300x185.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn88@2020_4/2020/08/23/15-18-19-953_c1cb72ce65de9128.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195880798},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:18:00","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:18:00","title":"AI Moving into Healthcare, Regulatory Challenges Await","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=165886","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/03/13/ai-moving-into-healthcare-regulatory-challenges-await/\" title=\"AI Moving into Healthcare, Regulatory Challenges Await\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"185\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/AI-Moving-into-Healthcare-Regulatory-Challenges-Await-300x185.jpg\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" alt=\"ai and healthcare\" style=\"margin-bottom: 15px;\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/AI-Moving-into-Healthcare-Regulatory-Challenges-Await-300x185.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/AI-Moving-into-Healthcare-Regulatory-Challenges-Await-260x160.jpg 260w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/AI-Moving-into-Healthcare-Regulatory-Challenges-Await.jpg 825w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></div><p>In recent years, artificial intelligence (AI) has started to turn up everywhere you look. It powers our ever-present digital assistants; it helps recommend entertainment options and has even begun to <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/04/15/how-ai-is-revolutionizing-global-logistics-and-supply-chain-management/\">reshape the way</a> businesses carry out their everyday operations. As AI moves further into healthcare, regulatory challenges await.</p>\n<p>The truth is, there isn&#8217;t a single major industry that isn&#8217;t being changed by the rapid development of AI-powered technology. There is one, though, that stands out among all others: healthcare.</p>\n<p>The <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/03/06/smart-cities-solving-todays-healthcare-challenges/\">global healthcare industry</a> arguably has more to gain from advances in AI than any other industry. It&#8217;s already being put to use in aiding diagnoses, monitoring patient health data to look for early warning signs of disease, and managing medication doses and prescriptions.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s even proven adept at <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2018/08/27/did-you-know-that-artificial-intelligence-could-predict-your-death/\">predicting patient mortality</a>. At the same time, however, the adoption of AI into healthcare carries some unique risks not found elsewhere – owing to the fact that any missteps can cost lives.</p>\n<p>That reality is rapidly setting up a conflict between the multitude of businesses that seek to develop healthcare-focused AI solutions. The regulators tasked with making sure the industry always puts the safety of patients first may have a problem.</p>\n<p>As an overview of what&#8217;s happening with AI and healthcare &#8212; here&#8217;s a look at the ways that healthcare AI solutions are pushing the regulatory envelope. The challenges it <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/12/09/internet-of-things-makes-it-easier-to-steal-your-data/\">creates for regulators to solve</a>.</p>\n<h2>Securing the Underlying Data</h2>\n<p>To begin with, AI solutions don&#8217;t work in a vacuum. They rely on complex infrastructures that bring together a variety of data sources from several disparate providers. When it comes to the healthcare industry that data may come from <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/01/10/improving-responses-to-medical-device-vulnerabilities/\">medical practices</a>, hospitals, <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/12/10/myia-healths-partnership-with-mercy-virtual-window-into-continuous-care/\">drug makers</a>, insurers, and any number of other intermediaries.</p>\n<p>The first challenge is in designing medical data integrations that adhere to existing medical privacy laws such as the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) in the United States and the <a href=\"https://www.healthcarefinancenews.com/news/europes-gdpr-privacy-law-coming-heres-what-us-health-orgs-need-know\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">General Data Protection Regulation</a> (GDPR) in the EU.</p>\n<p>The problem, as it relates to regulation, is the fact that there&#8217;s no one-size-fits-all standardized platform to handle medical data. Most of what&#8217;s already in use or in development consists of custom database solutions that were never designed to be interoperable.</p>\n<p>That makes every link between such systems a<a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/03/04/artificial-intelligence-forecasts-for-2020/\"> potential privacy nightmare</a>. That alone will require some time to remedy, and there&#8217;s no telling what the ultimate solution will be. In addition, when you add AI to this mix, things get even more muddled.</p>\n<p>For example, many of today&#8217;s medical AI systems have used real-world patient data to learn how to do their intended functions. That data is normally anonymized before being used for machine learning purposes, but studies have already confirmed that it&#8217;s often possible for such data <a href=\"https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamanetworkopen/fullarticle/2719130?resultClick=3\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">to be re-associated</a> with the people who generated it. That means there&#8217;s still a major data privacy concern even after current standards are applied to prevent one, and regulators are going to have to come up with entirely new guidelines for and oversight of new medical data sharing platforms and how they handle sensitive information.</p>\n<h2>Approving a Moving Target</h2>\n<p>Another regulatory challenge that current medical AI developments are creating is the fact that they&#8217;re distinctly different from all previous devices, medications, and technologies that have come before.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s because the <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/01/01/4-high-potential-sectors-for-ai-and-ml-startup-success/\">latest AI solutions</a> in the medical field are being designed to learn as they gain exposure to new patient data in order to hone their ability to make diagnoses, assist doctors, or suggest treatments.</p>\n<p>That means the capabilities, safety, and efficacy of some of the newest medical AI solutions can&#8217;t be assessed a single time for regulators to grant approvals.</p>\n<p>Unlike medications and standard medical devices, applied <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/01/06/6-industries-blockchain-technology-will-revolutionize/\">AI in medicine is a moving target</a>. Whereas a non-AI device can undergo thorough testing and gain approval, an AI&#8217;s performance may be different the day after its undergone testing. What&#8217;s more, there&#8217;s no telling if the performance differences will make it work better or worse.</p>\n<p>That&#8217;s why regulators like the US&#8217;s Food and Drug Administration (FDA) have thus far only started to approve locked-algorithm solutions <a href=\"https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/fda-permits-marketing-artificial-intelligence-based-device-detect-certain-diabetes-related-eye?utm_campaign=PR_FDA%20permits%20AI%20device%20for%20diabetes%20eye%20problems&#38;utm_medium=email&#38;utm_source=Elo\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">like IDX Technologies&#8217; IDx-DR eye scanner</a>.</p>\n<p>When medical AI has the ability to learn, however, all of the existing approval processes no longer suffice. To tackle the problem, the FDA has already proposed a <a href=\"https://www.nextgov.com/emerging-tech/2019/04/fda-proposes-regulations-ai-powered-medical-devices/156109/\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">whole new regulatory framework</a> to deal with AI in medical applications. It would include a preapproval process that would allow manufacturers some leeway in what changes (or how much machine learning) would be permissible without re-approval. In addition, it would require manufacturers to submit ongoing performance data to the agency so they can intervene if necessary. That, however, will require a drastic increase in manpower at the FDA – and nobody&#8217;s sure if they&#8217;ll get it.</p>\n<h2>Dealing with Black Boxes</h2>\n<p><figure id=\"attachment_165890\" aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-165890\" style=\"width: 900px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img class=\"wp-image-165890 size-full\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/ai-healthcare-black-box.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"900\" height=\"500\" srcset=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/ai-healthcare-black-box.jpg 900w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/ai-healthcare-black-box-300x167.jpg 300w, https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/ai-healthcare-black-box-260x144.jpg 260w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px\" /><figcaption id=\"caption-attachment-165890\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Photo: taa22 / Adobe Stock</figcaption></figure></p>\n<p>Just as it&#8217;s the case in the broader world of AI development, regulators of healthcare AI solutions are going to have to grapple with the prevalence of black-box AI software. AI seems to present a double-edged sword in healthcare. If we restrict developers from protecting their work too much, and innovation stops.</p>\n<p>However, let devs have free reign, and there won&#8217;t be any way to know if the approaches in use are what&#8217;s best for the patients that will rely on the technology.</p>\n<p>To solve that problem, regulators are going to have to strike a delicate balance that allows developers some means of protecting trade secrets while providing enough transparency to allow for thorough vetting of healthcare algorithms. That&#8217;s going to require regulators across a variety of agencies to bring high-level AI developers into the fold, as they&#8217;ll be the only ones qualified to figure out what the AI solutions are doing and why.</p>\n<p>Those developers will also need a medical or research background to be able to comprehend the medical aspects of the technology. That in itself is a problem because there aren&#8217;t too many people that can satisfy both requirements at present, and there&#8217;s no existing program designed to <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/01/01/4-high-potential-sectors-for-ai-and-ml-startup-success/\">produce such experts</a>.</p>\n<h2>A World of Innovation Complications</h2>\n<p>Although it is certain that AI holds the power to revolutionize almost everything about the modern healthcare industry, the regulatory issues identified here must be solved if it&#8217;s to happen in a <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/02/08/detecting-and-protecting-against-ransomware-best-practice-for-2020/\">safe and controlled manner</a>.</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2019/03/08/ways-enhanced-technology-has-changed-the-nature-of-business/\">Regulatory issues</a> will require something of a parallel revolution to take place within the relevant regulatory bodies that oversee the industry. It&#8217;s going to take new approaches, expanded oversight, and the development of a new generation of medical AI experts. Needless to say, paying for all of the regulations won&#8217;t be a trivial matter, either.</p>\n<p>For all of those reasons, it&#8217;s easy to foresee that the required changes are not going to happen overnight. There isn&#8217;t a roadmap for regulators or developers to follow, and that means they&#8217;ll have to blaze a trail together into healthcare&#8217;s AI-powered future.</p>\n<p>Blazing a trail means the need for all sides to be cautious and take the time to get things right on the first try may prove to be the ultimate limiting factor in AI&#8217;s spread into the industry. That, of course, is how it should be.</p>\n<p>After all, the consequences of <a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/02/11/outsource-or-automate-how-to-strategically-take-tasks-off-your-plate/\">failure to regulate</a> would be dire and irreversible &#8212; and in healthcare, there are real human lives that hang in the balance.</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/03/13/ai-moving-into-healthcare-regulatory-challenges-await/\">AI Moving into Healthcare, Regulatory Challenges Await</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://readwrite.com\">ReadWrite</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 13 Mar 2020 18:00:28 +0000","feedId":271,"bgimg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/AI-Moving-into-Healthcare-Regulatory-Challenges-Await.jpg","linkMd5":"c1095f60295084218ac626738c785ac5","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn39@2020_6/2020/08/23/15-18-23-202_22dc8c5544930089.webp","metaImg":"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/AI-Moving-into-Healthcare-Regulatory-Challenges-Await.jpg","destWidth":825,"destHeight":510,"sourceBytes":39229,"destBytes":30892,"author":"Andrej Kovacevic","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/AI-Moving-into-Healthcare-Regulatory-Challenges-Await-300x185.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn60@2020_3/2020/08/23/15-18-13-784_476d659e69c098bf.webp","https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/ai-healthcare-black-box.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn92@2020_2/2020/08/23/15-18-21-707_1ff8a5c463fa44d6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598195880530},{"createdTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:51","updatedTime":"2020-08-23 23:17:51","title":"5 Reasons Why You Should Absolutely Embrace Social Media Marketing","link":"https://readwrite.com/?p=173131","description":"<div><a href=\"https://readwrite.com/2020/07/29/5-reasons-why-you-should-absolutely-embrace-social-media-marketing/\" title=\"5 Reasons Why You Should Absolutely Embrace Social Media Marketing\"><img width=\"300\" height=\"225\" src=\"https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Absolutely-Embrace-Social-Media-Marketing-300x225.jpg\" class=\"attachment-medium size-medium wp-post-image\" https://images.readwrite.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Absolutely-Embrace-Social-Media-Marketing-900x674.jpg 900w,
